Let me say right at the outset that I am not overly concerned about historical accuracy in a TV drama series or a work of historical fiction.  I do enjoy the kind of speculation that Philippa Gregory engages in when the information available is inconclusive about a certain person or event. I am happy to run with any number of theories about the fate of the Princes in the Tower, I am OK with Perkin Warbeck being Richard of Shrewsbury, I am alright with Princess Lizzie having an affair with her uncle,  and I am OK with Elizabeth Woodville practicing witchcraft for real. I do draw the line at completely unattested, invented allegations like Henry VII raping his bride-to-be, but I am fine with all the rest, where there are historical rumors and allegations on which to base the speculation.  If this makes your blood boil, this show is not for you.

This series started out slow, but then gained momentum and finished very strongly, IMO.

I've read the three books this series is based on, and other books on the Wars of the Roses, so I had no trouble keeping the characters straight. I am not sure that this is a simple task for someone who has no knowledge of the period. Things move very quickly in the later episodes.
Here's my assessment of the strength and weaknesses of the show-

The Bad-
1) Visual anachronisms- Zippered dresses, concrete steps, men's jackets that look like they were bought from a department store, people without headdresses and such.

2) Some inexplicable decisions regarding the aging of characters- This series opens in 1464. Henry Tudor would have been a boy of about 7 at the time, and indeed at this stage he is played by a kid, and we see him go through various stages of growth. He is a young man of 28 when the series ends in 1485.  However, Richard III ought to have been a boy of 12 at the beginning of the series and a man of 32 at the end of it, but he is played by the same actor throughout. Likewise for the Neville sisters. Similarly, lady Margaret Beaufort looks the same from start to finish, but Elizabeth Woodville is aged a bit in the last couple of episodes .

3) Some events that took place are shown differently in the series, even though they are described correctly in the books. The execution of Hastings is left out for some reason (maybe to make Richard III look better?), and his attributes are given to Anthony Woodville. The historical Anthony was accompanying Edward V on his journey from Ludlow to London, and was arrested along the way, and later executed. Here, Anthony is in London, trying to broker some sort of deal between his sister and Richard and he is sleeping with Jane Shore. In reality, it is Hastings who had Shore as his mistress. I did not see the point of this distortion.

4) Budgetary Constraints - It showed in many ways. The sets and locations were underpopulated. The Battle of Bosworth Field had to be staged in a forest because staging it in a field would require more extras, horses and other props. The characters seemed to have a very limited number of outfits. The same buildings were being used to depict Westminster and Middleham and Clarence's residence. There just weren't enough  guards, servants, handmaidens and suchlike for it to look authentic.

5) Max Irons just isn't able to project the toughness and savvy of a monarch who lost and regained his grip on power twice during the course of the series.

That's a pretty long list of shortcomings.
Now, for the Good-

1) The agency given to the women. They are not appendages of the men. They are movers and shakers in their own right.

2) The cast- With the notable exception of Max Irons, the rest of the cast is very good.

Elizabeth Woodville is one of my favorite characters from the books and Rebecca Ferguson nails her completely. She is beautiful and smart and unforgiving and tough as nails. It isn't often that a character in film turns out just as you had imagined them upon reading the book.

Amanda Hale has a tough job trying to humanize a character that comes across a bit caricaturish in the books. Philippa Gregory evidently has Yorkist sympathies. The Lancastrians usually don't come across very well in her writings. Margaret Beaufort is fanatical and a bit of a hypocrite in the books, and though she retains those characteristics in the series, she also comes across as vulnerable and doubtful about the nobility of her purpose, which makes her less grating.

Aneurin Barnard makes a fantastic Richard III. As a nice guy who overreaches and does some questionable things and  finally sees his world disintegrate, he manages to be both morally ambiguous and oddly sympathetic. The shot of the dead staring eyes of Richard as he lies stripped at Bosworth will forever remain seared into my brain.

Rupert Graves is a riot as Lord Stanley. His dynamic with lady Margaret is great. He has the funniest scene in the series where he teases his wife about how Princess Lizzie is having an affair with her uncle. The way he pauses before describing the piece of gossip as "juicy"  had me in splits.

3) The characterization of Princess Lizzie. Elizabeth of York is too much of a quiet, retiring, non-confrontational type in Tudor period writings. I loved that she is portrayed as a feisty teenager in this series who talks back to both her mother and future mother-in-law. She seemed so much like a regular headstrong rebellious teenager that I had no trouble forgiving her for doing inappropriate things like having a crush on her uncle and not showing a whole lot of consideration for her aunt.

On balance, I liked this very much . Aneurin Barnard has a new fan. The guy has a good singing voice. If only Richard and Henry had a sing off at Bosworth, it would save Princess Lizzy a lot of heartache.

A co-worker recommended THE WHITE QUEEN to me not knowing that I am fascinated by the TUDOR era in England. I didn't realize THE WHITE QUEEN is the story of Edward IV and his commoner wife Elizabeth Woodville (the white queen of the series). I knew their story and the story of the Princes in the Tower and the rise of the Tudor kings.

THE WHITE QUEEN takes the basic facts and weaves a tale of romance, espionage, war, betrayal, lust and heartbreak. The general facts are there but the story is fictionalized to entertain the audience. I was totally hooked by the story, the actors, the setting and everything about this series. I already knew how things would turn out so I was curious as to how the story would be told. This was a remarkable time in English history when no one was safe and loyalties shifted by the day. Women often played a powerful role and their place in history has been overlooked and THE WHITE QUEEN attempts to remedy this.

It's a stylized mini-series to admire and behold. It's a beautiful and stunning series to watch. The actors are beyond compare and I only recognized one or two actors so it all seemed so fresh. The series is based on a novel by Philippa Gregory who has blended history with fiction and romance. Again, the basic facts are here but it's still a fictionalized account. Hopefully, this stunning series will encourage you to research the historical facts (as they are known). Truth is stranger than fiction.

If you're a fan (as I am) of costume drama and a student of English history you will LOVE this series!  The acting is superb, the costuming and settings very authentic-looking (except of course that everybody looks way too clean and their teeth are too white and straight), and the scripts are well written and suspenseful.  And this is even tho those of us who know about the War of the Roses know how it all turns out.  I was especially pleased that Richard III wasn't portrayed as the hackneyed Shakespearean monster of yore but instead as the conflicted and complicated individual I'm sure he was.  Plus I think it was a brilliant move to keep us guessing as to who really killed the princes in the Tower.  Buckingham?  Richard himself?  Someone else who was trying to curry either Yorkist or Lancastrian favor?  After almost 550 years, unless some new information gets unearthed, we'll probably never know.

Although much of the costuming is horrible, and Yorkist England never had sheer interior curtains on windows, there is at least an attempt at a reasonable presentation of material culture.  The cast is excellent save for the Wydville family; Janet McTeer is an excellent Jacquetta Wydville, but frankly the rest of the tribe is presented as too plain.  Sir Richard & Jacquetta were famed for their striking looks, and their entire family of children took after them.  The casting of Max Irons & Rebecca Ferguson is especially good; I really believed I was looking at Edward IV and Elizabeth.  Again, the production did not degenerate Edward nearly enough for his documented physical condition when he met his end; much like "The Tudors" didn't do Henry VIII justice at the end with Jonathan Rhys-Meyers' physical presentation.  The history overall is good; I'm not fond of the whole "they really worked magic" theme that pervades Philippa Gregory's books, but that's her choice to make & she is a huge publication success.  The actress who portrayed Margaret Beaufort did an especially nice job working with a character that reads rather flat in the histories.

This reveals just how dangerous life must have been for the royals during the 15th century. The viewer cannot help but feel that danger as the constant maneuvering goes on to gain the throne of England. King Edward marries a commoner who is labeled a witch. We get the sense of that possibility, inherited supposedly, from her mother with indications that she, Queen Elizabeth, has passed that ability on to one of her daughters. Of course superstition was rampant so it didn't take much, when her sister-in-law loses her baby boy (a precious commodity since that child would be in line for the throne) in childbirth, for Elizabeth to be accused of being a witch. Elizabeth, the White Queen,ner, is hated because she is a commoner and because she has the ear of the king. Needless to say the intrigue is relentless and exhausting. I can only imagine that life, difficult as it was in those times, was intensely more so in the house of royalty-never knowing where the next "attack" might come from. The women who play the major roles (Elizabeth, her mother Jacquetta, Margaret d'Anjou and Mary) give very fine performances. The minimally lesser roles of Isabelle and Anne also very well done. Max Irons, son of the actor Jeremy Irons and actress Sinead Cusak, is  King Edward. And even with his baby face, he is very convincing in the role. An excellent production

Why do the producers, directors, etc. feel it is necessary to embellish a fascinating period piece with unnecessary distractions? No woman who has birthed 12 kids looks that good. And Edward got fat - why are we not treated to that sight?
BTW: I'm no prude, and enjoy a week-toned body as well as the next. But, there is a time and a place.

This show was very well done. Casting was excellent, though Elizabeth of York seemed a little too forcefully acted in an ensemble of subtle-yet-masterful performances. Writing was mostly excellent, though a few episodes toward the end seemed a little out of tune in the dialogue - then again, by that point in the story, with so many Edwards and Richards and Thomases running around, I suppose even a mother must refer to "your brother Thomas Grey" when speaking to another of her children. I haven't read Philippa Gregory's novels, upon which this show was based, but I'm definitely interested in doing so now. And it was nice to learn about royals that were lesser known to me - Henry VIII's parents, grandparents and so forth. I'm glad this was available on Prime, else I'd have never seen it.

I've only watched 2 or 3 episodes so far, but can't wait until I have the time to binge on this beautifully produced and well acted story.  I read the book and had a bit of a hard time visualizing the characters, but I may read it again now that I can put faces with names.  So far, it is faithful to the book and gorgeous to look at.  I can see why King Edward defied his family for Elizabeth, a beautiful, strong woman of great courage.  I happen to be an English history buff, but I can see how watching this series might make a buff out of those who thought they weren't particularly interested.  There is always a wide gap between fiction and history, but it often encourages one to seek out the reality after being so enchanted with the fictionalized version.  That's what happened to me at age 13 after reading a novel about Anne Boleyn.

There are many good things to appreciate about this series, particularly the acting, but what knocks it down a notch in my eyes is that it turns the screenwriting mantra "show, don't tell" on its head.  We are constant witnesses to characters rushing on screen to "tell" an important character what has happened off screen.  We seldom get to see that important event happen, and when we do the producers screw it up.  For example, the ultimate Battle of Bosworth Field, which took place in August 1485, happens in this series in a forest with snow on the ground.  Please, producers, could you not find a field to film the battle in, and do it at an appropriate time of the year?

A riveting tale, although it is quite liberal with historical accuracy.  It seems to have played up all the rumors and myths that were put out at during the reigns of Edward IV and Richard III concerning Elizabeth Woodville and her family, Mistress Jane Shore, Elizabeth of York and Richard III, and the fate of the younger of the two murdered princes, Richard Plantagenet.  Also, not for younger viewers due to a generous helping of graphic sex scenes and frontal nudity.  However, it still is a beautifully filmed story replete with beautiful faces, gorgeous scenery, and very gifted actors.  My critique is not meant to turn anyone away, as it is a pleasure to watch.  I have done so at least twice and will no doubt watch it several times again.  ,

So far, I'm enjoying it immensely. I loved the novel -- it is one of Phillippa Gregory's very best books -- and I was afraid of soiling my pleasure in the book with a made-for-TV drama. But I was wrong. This is excellent.

I will say one mean thing: somehow, I don't think William Morris wallpapers were very popular in the 15th century. The excessive use of them on the sets makes for a very pre-Raphaelite feeling to the series. But I can overlook that. Everything else is superb.

I read all of the books in The Cousins War series, by Phillipa Gregory. I found it such a fascinating period of history, especially as told through the eyes of women from several generations, and from opposing sides. This series carries on the stories told in the books at a deeper level, and really brings the characters to life. It took me a few episodes to really get into this series, but now, half way through, I am fully immersed in the drama and intrigue of political life at court. Having read the books, I enjoy knowing some of the political history that preceded this time period, and some of the personal histories of the characters in this show. If you enjoy historical fiction, I would highly recommend this series!!

A detailed account of the precarious life of this queen, danger at every stage, treason and betrayal at work constantly, both obvious and unknown. Lost of lives of loved ones, fear of the future of her sons, her husband's reign being questioned even by members of his own family, jealousy, envy, frequent wars to defend the reign... And, in the middle of all this, mysticism, the ability to foresee the dubious future and the anxiety, the uncertainty of not knowing if the visions were correctly interpreted or not. In one word, a masterpiece drama with a masterful performance of the cast!

I adore Phillipa Gregory, so I was excited to see this. I've only read one of the books, though, that were used for source material. I thought they did a really cool job of representing the mystical ideas that Gregory presented in the White Queen (the book). But I think it was a little harder to digest as a tv show than it was as a book. Maybe it just wasn't the right medium for me. The characters aged decades during the single season, and major battle, perhaps even a whole small war could boil up and resolve in a single episode. It was a little hard to keep track of, and felt a little superficial. Forget time for character development, which I thought largely fell a little flat. The women depicted are truly amazing, and they were as well done as possible in the amount of time they had. Four stars for a great effort, but don't watch this right after Outlander, or you WILL be disappointed.

The White Queen' has all the pageantry of GoT and all the Machiavellian plotting of HoC.
 I especially love that in 'White Queen' Richard III is a loyal and good-hearted man, turned into the  paranoid tyrant we know and hate by the crown, and that he is at last exonerated of killing his nephews.
I also love that the Kingmaker's daughters, raised as their ambitious parents' pawns, become equally obsessive and heartless players as adults.  In this world everyone is culpable and nobody deserves the crown, neither by incontrovertible blood right nor by superior kingcraft... it's all scheming, war, money, and politics.
 'The White Queen' makes an excellent companion piece to 'Lady Jane'  if you want to bracket the Tudors.  And If you want to follow the whole saga of bloodletting, ambition, and truly startling legal justifications that marked England from the death of Edward III to the coronation of James I, watch 'The Other Boleyn Girl' between 'the White Queen' and 'Lady Jane.'

This is a mini-series in the sense that it only consisted of one season, but that was always the plan from what I understand.  It's a complete story, spanning many years.  The combining of the three books into one series was brilliant.  The story leads us through the events with the White Queen, the Red Queen, and the Kingmaker's daughter as based on the novels.  I loved Max Irons and I think Rebecca Ferguson was perfect as Elizabeth Woodville.  The story is fast-paced and the acting is top rate.  This is one of Starz's best miniseries.

I don't know how I never heard of this series before now.  It more than likely had to do with the fact it was on Starz network.  I am incredibly disappointed to find that they did not continue the show.  It is truly entertaining television.  If you like steamy, scandalous, period shows then you must watch this.  I am sure that there are a great many historical inaccuracies but it's a drama not a documentary. The main characters all existed and many of the events happened in real life as well. I loved every single actor they cast.  I think they did a great job.  I was so intrigued with this show I found myself doing my own research to find what had been the fates of all the characters. I was particularly interested in the mystery of the "princes in the tower." It's a very fascinating story of the emergence of very strong women in a world ruled by men.

The White Queen was simply superb.  So much attention is given to Henry VIII and Elizabeth I.  They seem to have overpowered the history of British sovereigns.  While fascinating in their own rights, what preceded and defined them included The War of the Roses, King Edward IV, his Queen Elizabeth, the Princes in the Tower, the downfall of the Duke of Clarence and ultimately King Richard III, and the marriage of the White Princess Elizabeth to Henry VII...so much happened during the time frame encompassed by the books.  The White Queen Season I led me to listen to all of the audio books in the series. I so wish the tv series continued for another season with The Red Queen, Margaret Beaufort.  She was quite a formidable presence in her own right.  Her invoking God's approval at every turn she makes by such tests as asking God to give her a sign if he disapproved of her plans, and upon neither hearing nor seeing such a sign, she believed fervently God approved.  Likewise, if something fortuitous happened, she could use to say it showed God's favor, too.  The books and tv series led me to a voracious appetite regarding history from this period.  It's fascinating to watch the ever constant attention to politics and  back room deals, religion and magic, familial ties.  Each book in the series adds different perspectives to the mix gives a broader and better understanding  the times.  Amazon would do well to produce the remaining books into additional seasons.  I do believe a continuing series would find quite the following.
love it

I really enjoyed this series. It was an interesting view of the history of the York and Lancaster conflicts. Seeing it through the eyes of the powerful women involved made me think of the history from a different perspective. Of course it is fiction but it is fun to speculate and the series put a personal spin on these women (even if it is not historically correct). Now I HAVE to read the books.

Wow. I have seen many (many!) period pieces, most of them made in and about Great Britain, Brittany, England, etc. I was a huge fan of The Tudors on . . . HBO, I think it was? And while the acting on that show was fantastic, the acting on The White Queen was par excellence. And where I couldn't wait for the next romp with Henry's latest beauty on The Tudors, in The White Queen that kind of thing almost detracted from the overall story. No other historical epic got me digging into history like this one has. And the more I read about that particular era, the more astonished I was at how amazingly accurate the storytelling was! I can suspend disbelief with the best of them, but in this case, I didn't have to, and more importantly, the actual story is better than any dramatic retelling. And except for the witchcraft element - I haven't seen anything about that, although that doesn't mean it doesn't exist - it was true to form in nearly every instance - that is, about 99% of the time. That is far, far more than can be said of the vast majority of Hollywood fare telling us the story is "based" on a true story, or "based" on a novel. Well, if that were the case, why can I not recognize it from the source material?

Anyway, The White Queen excels in every arena - mystery, intrigue, action, drama, romance, and pretty much every other genre you can think of. I have already recommended the show to my best friends, and now I would like to recommend it to you. I promise, if you like period pieces like this, you will not be disappointed.

Great series. Very entertaining, and manages to be so without a lot of violence, which I found refreshing, since many of the current medieval-inspired series' are very violent (mind you, I enjoy them too, but this is a nice break from all that). Obviously, it's historical fiction, emphasis on the fiction part. Most of the characters are from real life, but their actual personalities are obviously invented by the author of the series or the screenplay writers. If that doesn't bother you, then I'd definitely recommend the series. The acting is, for the most part, excellent, the costumes are lavish, the sets are beautiful, and it manages to keep you on the edge of your seat throughout the whole series.

An excellent production of a very good adaptation of Philippa Gregory's novel.  The acting is strong and the depiction of Medieval England seems quite realistic.  Gregory's take on Richard of Gloucester (later Richard III) is novel --especially to those of us who first met him through the propaganda of Shakespeare.  What strikes us is how beautiful (and young!) King Edward and his Queen Elizabeth are.  Since it's a story of the battles of strong-willed and powerful women, it is short on blood and gore and very long on plotting and dialogue.  That makes it in a way more suspenseful, though perhaps less appealing to the Game of Thrones crowd.  It compares well to "The Tudors" and "The Borgias."  We can only hope that there will be a sequel, Gregory's "The White Princess."

If you enter this with the anticipation of being well-entertained, not necessarily schooled, you can sit back and enjoy - very engaging and romanticized version of the story of Edward IV and Elizabeth Woodville. I did not know exactly what this was about until I started watching it (other than it was an icon in my Prime Recommended lists); I thought it was purely fiction but because of the historical bent, I enjoyed this much more than expected (like, immensely!). I agree with the other reviewers to take the history with a grain of salt, but it's intended to be a dramatization, not a documentary. It did pique my interest enough in the history to verify/research the context around it and to re-watch the Henriad*.  I found the angle from the female protagonists to give this a unique and effective spin. There is some nudity and sex, but not obnoxiously so, and might be appropriate for older teens or slightly younger with parental guidance. I do think it potentially could be a useful platform in engaging students in English history. Great casting.

* "Henriad" - For background to the conflicts and agendas in The White Queen, check out Shakespeare's trio of King Henry plays (Henry IV Parts 1 and 2, and Henry V) and Richard II which precedes these. I highly recommend The Hollow Crown video series (featuring Jeremy Irons and Tom Hiddleston), which is based on the Shakespearean plays. Another recommendation for the storyline toward the end of The White Queen is a stylized, alternative version of Richard III (Edward IV's brother) featuring Ian McKellen and Annette Bening.

Very, very, well done.  Story line, acting, costumes, etc are all top notch and based on historical fact.  If you enjoy English Kings, Queens, Lords, and Ladies, you'll enjoy this historically accurate Game of Thrones based on King Edward IV, Queen Elizabeth, War of the Roses and the history of the York and Lancaster Royal families.

As an armchair historian (I have a degree in history/econ.) that has spent a fair amount of time studying this time period I have noticed that there are definitely creative liberties that have been taken, but I found this to be an enjoyable piece of historical fiction. In other words, I loved it!

Love Gregory's books.  One critic pointed out production's potrayal of a cleaned up medieval Britain, etc., but this viewer does not need  the realistism of poverty, disease, etc. of that time.  I binged it and thanks Amazon for procuring it.  On a scale of 5, I'd give it a 4-.

I adore this book and DVD. I am fascinated with the true story of the Lancaster, York and Tutor reigns. The author does an amazing job of incorporating history with the lives of the women who were married to men of power. I loved the book and movie so much that I began doing my own research on the cousins' war. These stories are very close to accurate. The author is kinder to the reader in some areas because we are not as accustomed to the cruelty of those times but it is still accurate enough to keep the history on track. I return to this three book series again and again.

This was another great show. I've watched the Tudors, Reign and this and it is all awesome. Especially since they take place in the same time period. Right now Reign is about Mary Queen of Scotts and her King Husband of France. Mary wanted the throne of England, but Queen Elizabeth, daughter of Ann and King Henry the 8th in the Tudors, became Queen when Queen Mary, Queen of England ( AKA Bloody Mary) died.

Shows like this are great for making people want to learn more about history. I didn't know much at all about the White Queen, but since I watched it after the Tudors I was interested in seeing it, since I read that her husband was King before the Tudors came to power.

I guess all I'm saying is this is a great show.

I have read all three of the novels which this series was based off of before watching it. My husband and I both really enjoyed watching this series; it was sumptuous and altogether addicting to see what would happen next. The screen adaption was done very well and the added focus on the main characters relationships with periphery character enhanced the story line. This series is refreshing because it takes place  just before the often done Tudor period. I would say the casting is superb, especially the actresses who play Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beauford and Anne Neville. I would recommend this series to anyone who enjoys a costume drama, excellent character development rounded out with realistic dialogue and rich depictions of historical events.

This series is well-acted and interesting.  It tells of the English monarchy just prior to the rise of Henry VIII and delves into the political "trading" that occurred as families and factions angled toward positions of power in the court.  The actors are not well-known, making it easier to concentrate on the characters and story rather than the celebrity of the players.

This was the best period drama I've seen in a long time. Gripping, well-acted (esp. King Richard with his mysterious, tortured eyes and terrible Margaret Beaufort (who was so very evil but believed herself a saint). Toward the end I could not stop watching it. The history is fascinating and appalling. Anyone who worships royalty should watch this for a different perspective. So many innocent people killed in the name of royal ambitions. One warning: this is dark, not at all a feel-good series. Even people you think you understand end up doing some unthinkable things. However, it is well worth watching. I wanted it to continue at the end.

Really wonderful series! It is about the War of the Roses, a very tumultuous time in England, Wales and French history among both the ruling class and aristocratic families just as the Renaissance Period was about to begin. Filled with lots of accurate costuming, architecture, politics and some war scenes showing the true brutality of hand to hand combat with steel blades. Series is not consumed by battle scenes and their horrors but does not down play them. Rather they focus on the process and progress which led to them and the outcome of those decisions on a broader scale.  Ravages of intermittent plague are really not focused on in the first season but we're still prevelant during this period of time. Perhaps second season will give this history making its due. Really looking forward to the coming season.

Great production and treatment of a hard to digest period of English history from the perspective of the women.  Better than Shakespeare at making clear the succession and power plays of late medieval royals.

My husband and I really enjoyed this. It was so well written and acted, and did a great job of making sense of a very complicated period of English history. We were surprised at how much care was taken with historical accuracy, remaining for the most part faithful to facts as far as we know them. There is so much debate about what actually happened that it would be impossible to make any claims to complete historical accuracy, but this show did a very good job of trying. The people and events are so interesting and dramatic that not a lot of embellishment is necessary to make a thrilling epic, which this is.
If you like historical fiction.  You may well like this.

The only detractor is that it was a one season shot that covered the entire reign of the York's.

A fantastic mini-series based on the novels about three strong, ambitious women. It's rare that movies or series devote themselves to the ambitions of women without portraying them in a malicious light. None of these women are perfect; however, their strengths, fanaticisms & ambitions portrays women as I've never seen before in their era. At a time when women were viewed as mere property--daughters to be married off for profit, given in marriage to men not of their choosing, submissive women used as pawns in the games of fortune--these women knew what they wanted. Almost every woman character in this series have iron wills of their own. And even when they don't have it in the beginning, they evolve and in the end, even to their own detriment, these women become forces to be reckoned with. Don't miss this beautifully adapted series. I've watched it a dozen times and each time, I marvel at some new tidbit that I'd missed in previous views.

I really enjoyed this series.  I studied British History in college and am fully aware of the areas that were condensed or expanded to fit the narrative story.  None of it significantly damaged the history and much of it made the story accessible and easy to understand for non-students of history.  Every bit of history we have is presented through the lens of the one who recorded it so looking at these events from a specific angle does not make any other view less real.  All that being said, I feel like this is one of the cases where history is better than fiction with all of the intrigue, double-dealing and second-guessing.  An absolute chess game played with the lives of the court and country folk alike.
The acting is great. I think the costumes looked cheap.

Yes, I admit that I came late to this program series. So many projects, so little time.
This is a fine piece of work by accomplished professionals. The cinematography is of
the highest quality (interesting overhead shots, for example), the production values
are outstanding, the script executed well, the credibility high--far higher than, for
example, another 'big name' series on the same general subject area that has attained
cult status. It is particularly pleasing to see a production in which the women get fair
treatment alongside the men (note to male chauvinists: if not for a woman, you would
not exist).
As for Rebecca Ferguson . . . words almost fail me. Her acting puts her in the top
rank of current women actors (check her out in the new Mission Impossible film
for another stirring example). Her diction is flawless, contrasting in this case with
the distressing Estuaryspeak of so many English actors and presenters today, where
'I' so often emerges as 'Oi' ('Oi loike' for 'I like') as a particularly egregious example.
Ferguson's French manicure strikes a slightly discordant note--it seems unlikely for
the era but some knowledgeable critic will no doubt set me straight if I am wrong, but
the devil is always in the details and this cost a star in my evaluation.

Fans of SHOWTIME's The Tudors will be encouraged to pick up this series as quickly as possible as it is a prequel of sorts to it.  White Queen goes back a generation to the War of the Roses and tells the tale of the rise of Henry VII (although he's not the main character in this story).  It details just how complicated and convoluted British history is with all of the twists & turns, shifting alliances and betrayals.

The ensemble cast is impeccable with Max Irons as a jolly fellow who does his best to be a good & just king (Edward IV) who marries a commoner.  Rebecca Ferguson is stunning as Elizabeth, the commoner who becomes queen of England.  Tudors alumni James Frain once more dons his medieval garb and portrays Warrick, the sinister brother of Edward.

Like The Tudors, this series has a genuine didactic feature;  I learned a lot from both series about an epoch in British history that I knew precious little about.  Both series are uncensored & uninhibited and do a fabulous job of taking the viewer back to the Middle Ages.  For lovers of history (like myself) this is a can't miss.  Who were Edward IV, Elizabeth Grey, Richard III and Henry VII?  Watch this series and by golly you'll find out.  Can't wait for season 2!!
Started watching out of curiosity, and got hooked.  Now I am reading the novels. Very well done.

I haven't read Phillipa Gregory's "The White Queen", but I read Sharon Kay Penman's "The Sun in Splendor," another fantastic writer of historic fiction.  For those interested in British History of this era I would highly recommend her whole series.  Their portrayals were very similar with a few major differences, such as the survival of the younger prince.  Sharon also referred to the possibility of his existence, but did not have him reunited with his Mother, The White Queen.  However since I have not as yet read Gregory's "The White Queen," this could have been poetic licence taken by the screen writers.  If there is a Season II, I will be very anxious to see it.

I heard this was a decent show and though I would give it a try. I rounded 2.5 stars up to 3. It moves through history too fast and doesn't give you a sense of passing time. It all feels as though things are happening all within a week or two when in reality years are going by. There is pretty much near to nothing in way of action, and it's dry and boring. All in all, it looks like someone has been trying to capitalize on the popularity of 'The Tudors,' and the mythical Middle Ages blockbuster,'Game of Thrones." The characters aren't developed well and it gives you no reason to cheer on, or hang onto a character. The problem is that 'The White Queen," is a mailed in hit or miss, for me, it's definitely a miss.

This is the story of the three women that schemed their way into the throne. Elizabeth Woodville is a commoner from the Lancaster family. King Edward IV falls in love with her. After this, a series of turbulent events make this series a must watch. Beautiful sceneries, intrigues, passion and political turmoil. These are the events previous to the Tudor dynasty. If you love this kind of story, then I recommend you watch it! I absolutely loved it. It is important to say that it is based on Philippa Gregory's novel, a historical fiction author.

I enjoyed this series, for the most part, I'm not sure how authentic it was as far historical events. The period clothing  was peppered with modern technology though. As zippers in the 1400's had not yet been invented and many full shots of dresses with full length zippers were shown throughout as one example. I tried to ignore those obvious details.
  I would have preferred them to have sex in private. There are a lot of more creative ways to imply two or more (in this film more) persons engaging in intercourse without  showing glimpses of gyrating unclothed body parts. For one thing the brain of the viewer fills in a much richer picture of the act than what they show grunting on my TV.  Or maybe that is all the director and actors gets from sex, it's a sad possibility. Which  it left a lot to be desired.
  The way they showed the violence was very creative, less graphic, it left no doubt in ones mind about what took place but left off most of the gore of the disgusting things that they did to each other.
  Also the movie did a good job of portraying the lack of science and importance of superstition, church and religion. The limit of medical knowledge and how much risk they were to dieing of commonly solved ailments of today was accurately portrayed making one realize that it more luck than skill or wit that resulted in the royal lineage.
  The scenery, castles and women's hair do's were all really incredibly beautiful.
  Story line kept me interested through the series and I found it entertaining and interesting with the actors playing their parts well.

We try not to get too interested in a series because we never know if it is going to be cancelled.  This is why we cancelled cable.  We paid a lot for cable and our shows were constantly getting cancelled.  It would be nice if Amazon, Netflix and Hulu would not offer series that are cancelled after one season.

A superb dramatic series, fittingly-cast, excellently-acted, and historically accurate (as well as racy) enough to present a relatively true-to-life picture of how the upper echelon of that time, not so differently from now, faced not uncommonly having to put aside love and affection for power and position in an arranged marriage, while maintaining viewers' attention during some of the more complicated twists of plot and action! The characters masterfully show us how following one's heart requires strategic manouevring, in order to bring off union with one's true love, while holding onto the reins of power and preserving one's reputation and the support of the people, by dispelling rumour and innuendo that could topple one at the apex of power. This series deftly illustrates the age-old dilemma pondered throughout human history: love or power? (Reviewed by Linda's husband)

This is my first review. Ever. For any Amazon product.  But that's how much I loved this series. It was compelling enough to rewatch. Compelling enough to make me pine for it every time I scroll past it and wish there were another season.
Don't get me wrong, this series scarcely nods at fact; I've got a Bachelor's degree in History that I have to hide in a drawer every time I watch this.  That said, the series makes suspending disbelief a seamless process, because the set design, good acting and quality writing transport the viewer to the world of The White Queen.  I'm a huge sceptic of Philippa Gregory, who wrote the book that the series is based on.  She takes already salacious history and vilifies female figures just for kicks, then claims her work is historically accurate.... but fortunately for all of us, the 'based on' accreditation has never been more accurate. It is based on, not a translation of her work to the screen.
So, in rough summation, even if you don't tend to enjoy historical shows, this one might change your mind.  Historical inaccuracy can be dismissed because the show weaves its own world.  The condensed course of time speeds the action, to prevent the torpor that can haunt historically based programs.  Perhaps most importantly, this show gives viewers what they wanted but never received when they went to see "The Other Boleyn Girl" or "The Tudors."

This was an unexpected treasure! The acting was flawless, the costuming and sets were done beautifully!
It showed the complexities of rulership and politics clearly while making it credible thru the excellent directorship throughout the series. The story of those vying for the crown is interwoven with history and yet the movie keeps to the personal drama of those involved.  Since this captures a relatively short period of history, it would be difficult to stretch into a longer running series, but I sure would have loved for it to continue!  The plot ever thickens! Too bad it could not have encompassed a longer period of history. I would enjoy seeing more of these types of historical fiction types of movies if they held as high a standard as the White Queen did.

The White Queen's time period of The War of the Roses was a time filled with intricate royal politics.  Superb casting allows the viewer to focus on the realities of the danger and the power struggles that were so much a part of the lives of the royals and anyone connected with them.  Nothing brings the strategies and the intricacies of these times to life as the good visuals that are so much a part of the White Queen. Even someone who is not necessisarily interested from a perspective of historical accuracy can easily be caught up in the drama and its participants.

A very enjoyable TV series. Ok, not 100% historically accurate, but then I am not sure that any period piece truly is, and there are definitely liberties taken with literary license...such as a few witches in the mix. Regardless, for me, what makes a series worthwhile is the entertainment value, especially the performances, and I felt that the actors and actresses portrayed their characters quite well. Some perhaps overly dramatized, but still extremely enjoyable. Watching the drama unfold with the who-dunits and the who is going to get it was paced well. This series should appeal to those who like mystery and intrigue, mixed in with intense familial relations, and a bit of love and lust thrown in for good measure (yes, definitely R-rated). Not as action-packed as Game of Thrones, not as sexually brutal as The Tudors, but if you like those two series, you should like The White Queen.

What probably sounded like a great idea was very poorly implemented. A fantasy piece focused on the women should have worked, however, the writers simply warmed over every cliche they could find to produce this work. The tagline "women wage war" is a joke. All the women in this series are powerless without their men, including the witch. How does that work? What good is it to be a witch who can alter the weather but can't stop her man from whoring around? These women are whiny, needy, and weak. I'd love to watch a series about women who, in fact, wage war. This one is not it.

The White Queen: Elizabeth Rivers- First of all, I wish to make mention of all the wonderful, brilliant, and altogether mentionable, REVIEWS I have read through before I decided to watch this Historical (fiction-like) mini-series.  I have read, more devoured, the novels.  Ms. Gregory pens a most clever tone in all of her works, to me this is undoubtable.  However, most who would even think of watching a show like this, are all too prepared to see it mashed up into pieces, finely or not-sliced and diced.  Reality hangs ever near the senses of those like me, who devour shows such as this.  THIS is a work of fiction and history mixed, focusing on the lives and drives of, not the men, but their women: queens, duchesses, princesses, Countesses...titles are just words.  However, in this particular time period those word-titles meant the crossing of barriers large and small. Nothing without a price, seems the primary lesson.

People here have completely picked up the info that this wonderful work is also, historical fact, for the most part.  A bit tender, bent-but nevertheless, fact.  In writing that sentence, I have to completely swing over to the production itself.

In a word?  Splendid.  Oh yes.

THIS production, as intricate and complex as it must have been, is beyond most of the adjectives I can consider, here.

I  could have spent several more happy hours watching additional episodes, it's that finely done.  Now, why couldn't I write something as good? Damn, what a task.  The garb, the sets, the special effects, all were fabulous to see.  There was no dearth of fine performers here, the intimate struggles for power, the manner in which we were shown this slice of history.  I simply cannot write more without possibly becoming repetitive.

IF I could have one bit presented with a tad more accuracy, it would be the assumption of the practice of Witchcraft.  There is no evil or devil in the craft.  As a consummate pagan, in the real world I am also by family,  a witch.  The representation in this series, has deemed that behavior/beliefs/ or reasoning  to be  evil and manipulative,  here assumed the primary life qualities of witches.  .Just that, a point of view.

In sum, this is a series to get your teeth into. One episode blends rather seamlessly into the next.  That kept me from sleeping a couple of nights.  Had to watch "Just one more" episode.  I highly recommend this series to anyone who can explore a time period not their own, but one painted in sublime colors.  This one is a keeper which just entered my wish list.  :)

This has become one of my favorite period pieces. It's fun and often painful to watch the struggles for power between the most powerful men (and women) in early England and Europe and the subjugation of the general populations. Soldiers are and always have been mostly cannon fodder for the ruling classup to and including WWIwhere they fought and died for the Kaiser, the Tsar and King George V, all "royal" cousins. Between these three cousins, they killed and maimed over 37 million people just over families feuding over power and land. These historic adaptations give one a good idea of how this all came to be.

The program was amazing and sent me to the books to look up all these people, who I never really heard of, except perhaps for Henry Tudor and even he wasn't who I thought he was.  What a strange time in England that must have been--never knowing who was King, never knowing when the next war would start. All those machinations. Additionally, the costumes and sets/scenes were amazing and I'm glad that the ladies didn't seem to be changing their dresses every other moment since that would be unrealistic.

I do love a good period piece and this certainly qualified.  Everything from the sets, locations, costumes, script and acting were top notch.  Its filled with drama, romance, angst, heartbreak and a little bit of humor here and there.
If you know a bit about this period in history then it gives you some different theories as to what happen to the princes in the tower and other events that took place during the War of the Roses.
I especially enjoyed the perspective of the untold stories of the women involved in this part of history.  The wives and daughters of noblemen who played a part in shaping England's history.  We've seen many films regarding Queen Mary, Queen Elizabeth I, and Anne Boleyn, but what about the women that came before them?  The White Queen gives us some of those stories in a brilliant and wonderful mini series.
Entertaining.  Many events correlate with historical data.

I love the TV series THE GOOD WIFE.  Why?  Extraordinary female characters.  If you like complicated, strong female characters in a historic period where they are not expected try THE WHITE QUEEN.  Now you history buffs, just take a deep breath, it is loosely based on English history, very loosely.  So forget that and enjoy the plat lines with the history presented.  The actresses, superb !  The cast is not made up of household stars for America but Rebecca Ferguson, Amanda Hale, and Faye Marsay deserve praise. But the females go on, Veerle Baetens, Janet McTeer, Julie Aubrey are juysta few more excellent women in strong roles.  Hey the series is free with PRIME.  Jump on that

It was way too fake looking.  Also, these are nobles.  Would they wear the same garment day after day?  Anne Neville wore that green dress with the awful fake fur every day for a very long time. This series would receive five stars except for its gratuitous nudity.  In the most boring way, you can expect that every episode will have its nude scene. This was a BBC/Starz co-production.  The version for the BBC did not include this element.  For some reason, Starz felt it was obligatory for the American audience, so it was shot just for us. How thoughtful!  In spite of this irritating pandering, the series is extremely well-done.  The directing and all technical elements are quite good.  Some of the photography is breathtaking.  All of the actors are young and very talented.  Though they take  arguable views about certain historic events and people, the scripts, which are based on historical fiction, are good.  As long you don't view it as defining absolute historical truth, this drama is very enjoyable.

I just finished episode 6 & looking forward to seeing the rest. People have very varied reviews of Phillippa Gregory & her books, I love her stuff. It may not be completely accurate historically but if I want facts I'll read a textbook. Her books grab me from page 1 until the end & this series is basically 3 books in 1. The writing (in my opinion) is good, the acting is good & the pace of story telling is good. The actress who plays Queen Elizabeth is breathtakingly beautiful & the actors who play her children could quite literally be her real children. They're resemblance is uncanny! I also like the actress who plays Jacquetta (Queen Elizabeth's mom). My only criticism is the amount of nudity & the sex scenes are fairly graphic. But overall I'm thoroughly enjoying this series.

I love this show for the historical fiction that it is. Phillipa Gregory is a hack as far as an historian but as an author she is a juicy enjoyable readable hack, but the twists she throws in should NEVER be used as reality for any truth of events that actually took place.

The show is very enjoyable, slightly better production than the Tudors, but highly anachronistic as far as costumes. Despite all that I found my self fully invested in the story by the end of the 2nd episode, and my husband was fully engaged by the end of the 4th. My heart did break for certain characters deaths and I found myself wanting to stab others in their evil little hearts.

The execution of Margaret Beaufort was extremely disappointing however. While they focused on her piety, they made her seem like a loon. All records that I've come across indicate she was a stoic serious women with high composure. She did not "break down" at least not according to the Tudor propaganda machine.

I would like to see a story done on the back bone of something like Jean Plaidy or Allison Weir. I respect those two authors for their research and historical fiction equally. PG is bubble gum history and fun, but not meaty.

Have you ever wondered how our politics became so competitive and self serving? The White Queen is a look at fifteenth century power struggles that are eerily characteristic of today. Money may have replaced swords, and the titles may have changed, but people have not. On another note, it is also interesting to see how powerful women were, even though their social and political status back then was nowhere near as great as it is today. One small disappointment is the occasional use of witchcraft.

Authentic and accurate portrayal of the 1400's era. I think after Game of Thrones came along and was so popular that a lot of knock offs have begun to pop up. Don't get me wrong, that's a good thing! And this series, The White Queen (so far) has been very interesting. This series is acted well. The directors got a good feel for the 1400's; because in reality, the dark ages of the 1400's were muddy, nasty, and only the Royalty and other upper society people such as priests and merchants were somewhat educated and could read,  whilst the other 99% of the population living in the cities lived in squalor and were illiterate. Sicknesses and diseases were rampant because of ignorance,  no one had a clue as to  what a germ or virus was. The scenery that this series is being shot in is breathtaking, no fakey sets here. And the actors are all convincing, the female actors aren't bodily enhanced babes, and the truth is, most men and women of royalty (because of inbreeding)  rarely looked like Brad Pit, or Angelina Jolie. So the male actors are fit and intense, but not Chip N Dale models. And everyone at least looks like they can actually ride a horse. In other words the cast was picked to portray "the reality" of the era.  Okay, the cons: E gads! have you EVER SEEN so many beheadings!?!? And that crown is like a hot potato! It has been on so many heads in such a short time that it must be a "one size fits all". The plotting and deceit whirl around so fast one can hardly keep up with who is who and what is happening. Allegiances, fealty, and trust is like a whisp of smoke, there one moment, gone the next! And I hate to even mention this...REALLY I do...But, I've seen more naked breasts in six episode of TWQ than I have ever seen in my entire life! And most of them were not pretty breasts either. I would have much preferred that some of the actors kept their tops ON. BUT, once again, the wardrobe, nudity, muddy cloaks, and a fantastic understanding of armour, weapons and the horses (which were beautiful and obviously superbly trained as one would expect for a time when horses were of  paramount importance) emparted a real feeling of authenticity. So all in all this is a good series. I have enjoyed it. I'm giving this a fiver because of the unabashed accuracy. The writers and directors didn't hold back. Would I recommend this to friends and everyone else, ABSOLUTELY yes. I like the grit of this series, but the plotting was just too much. If you dozed off for five minutes, the crown would he on someone else's head....and there would be another head rolling off the chopping block!

I am really enjoying this first season and like the choices of actors for the parts.  I'm sure there are challenges to historical accuracy in some of the storyline, but overall it seems portrayed very well and helps to bring history to life in a way that is more readily memorable, as you can associate a face and potential character with the names, as well as the weaving of layers of relationships - much like it is to remember personal family history and it's nuances, as opposed to memorizing general history from a more linear textbook scenario.
One of my all time favorites.

My husband and I are Britophiles, so when we discovered a piece based on a novel by Phillipa Gregory about the period that precedes Henry VIII and the Tudors, well - we had to see it.  That said, we can only wonder about the veracity of some of these intrigues, but then, it is historical *fiction*, and in this bodice-ripper kind of atmosphere, I would put the emphasis on the *fiction* part. (For instance, I doubt that everyone was so terminally good-looking or clever and had perfect pearly white teeth.)  But it's good entertainment and at least we have some better idea of the conflict between the Lancasters and the Yorks.  Enough that maybe I'll have to go back and actually read about it.

Tired of endless series and movies about Henry the Eighth?  If so, try Henry the Sixth instead!  Set in about 1450 in England, this series highlights the long-term struggle between the houses of Lancaster and York over the English throne.

Henry is actually a side-show in this series as he is already mentally ill and incapable of understanding what is going on, and he is shunted aside early on.  Instead, the series focuses on the new King Edward and his struggles with his brother and the traitorous Earl of Warwick.

The show is well made with strong, believable acting and high production values (great costumes and backdrops).  The plot is fairly easy to follow even if you don't know much about English history.

A well acted period drama for those of us interested in English royal history.  Actually, the themes of this drama are timeless even if the personages are powerful members of the royal court in 14th century England. There is no end to the machinations of princes, kings, queens and courtiers in the quest to gain and keep power.
 I found the series to be very modern in it's managing of character development. Many a minor character and occasionally a major one is sent to his doom because of misunderstood or misperceived motives.  Everyone suspects everyone else of plotting for advantage and advancement.  The divided loyalties, suspicion, intrigue and down right paranoia make for a faster pace than many period dramas in which there is more dialogue than action. If you enjoy the genre, this drama will keep your interest.

I watch television shows as if they were long movies- I get lost in the fantasy. As someone who watched and mostly enjoyed The Tudors, I find The White Queen so much more interesting and compelling. It is well-acted, beautiful and beautifully filmed, and has just the right amount of magic. Magic runs as an undercurrent throughout the season and delicately balances the realities of burnt witches and Arthurian legend.

For some reason, I found this Jane Austen quote bouncing around in my head during the first few episodes:
I read it [history] a little as a duty, but it tells me nothing that does not either vex or weary me. The quarrels of popes and kings, with wars or pestilences, in every page; the men all so good for nothing, and hardly any women at all  it is very tiresome: and yet I often think it odd that it should be so dull, for a great deal of it must be invention. - Jane Austen

Instead of being dull, the political intrigues and courtly slights are the compelling sword play in this series. I think Jane would have been pleased that the story is told through the eyes and words of women. The philandering king is portrayed as buffoonish. His extramarital romps are not celebrated as Henry's are in The Tudors, but rather are seen as his weakness.

I was tempted to budge watch this series, but they are so lush and engaging that I have been trying to watch them more slowly. If you are looking for a new British period drama, Look no further than The White Queen!

I'm now tempted to re-watch "The Tudors" just to prolong the experience.

Having read all four books that comprised the dramatization of the White Queen I have to say that I was very pleased with the outcome.  I found the book details became a bit repetitious (and on occasion contradictory) since the same events were witnessed and reported through various principal characters who obviously perceived them their own priorities and agendas. The screen writers synthesized the four books into a well conceived whole, while still maintaining the contradictory and contentious nature of the main characters.  Production values and costumes were lush and the acting was excellent.  Very well done, and looking forward to the planned (I hope) Sequel, The White Princess.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

OK so my historical background of this war is rather limited. I found the "War of the Roses" to be about as convoluted as this inception and was prepared to expect less from the get go.

I did not find the sex scenes gratuitous, but the harrowing birthing scenes ad nauseum, pahleeze! I imagine this POV was to exhibit the empowerment of women but I never really appreciated this in dialogue, presence and plot. All I perceived was fear, suspicions, witchcraft, voodoo, and plain ol sissy stuff. Everyone was polluted with a power trip and was a predictable plot element.

Lady Margaret's facial expressions were painful vs sympathetic and found her role annoying and discomforting. Her ultimate reward for her patience and strong beliefs were powerful but diluted with her poor acting.

I had no concept of how intricate the plot thickens as the series progresses and was ill prepared for the complexities as I did a power play and watched the entire season in 2 sittings. What did viewers do after an entire week of not recalling names, faces, goals, and devious deeds. This timeframe represents an incredible history lesson and the producers needed to slow down to allow us fledglings to comprehend the full repercussions of family ties.

High recommend for dysfunctional family sympathy and a hint of how crazy royal life was for a spell. I do not think the peasants were as much affected as their lives were already horrific. Dark material with few breathers.
Good period series

I've only watched the first four episodes and I'll jump on episode 5 as soon as I can.  This makes the current posturing by our current Democrat and Republican candidates look pretty tame. Think about House of Cards set in merry old England way back when with some witchcraft tossed in.

Well, there seems to be a growing trend to capitalizing on the naughty-to-really-bad British Royalty and their doings in and out of bed. This series makes use of all the essential items - nude bodies, graphic simulated sex, some factual history, really bitchy mothers and daughters, etc. They DO skip some of the better known facts (Richard III does not have curvature of the spine. I did enjoy this series, but it does move at such a brisk pace that character development suffers. Elizabeth never seems to evolve very much from being dependent on her mother to being paranoid (understandably so) in court. She and Edward don't seem to age at all, even though she bears several children and he's off fighting wars. One thing I took away from this was a wonderment that anyone would want to sit on that throne, since it seems to do nothing but invite trouble. Very enjoyable overall, though, with good acting and plenty of beautiful historical details, and all the twists and turns history provides.

When learning about England and their kings and queens, Im often overwhelmed about how vicious, greedy, vindictive, immoral, and conniving these royals were about their family dynasties. The crown seemed to be the focal point of life, and killing, clawing, and stealing to sit upon the monarchs chair and wear the jewels made monsters out of most of them. Loyalties shifted like the weather, and to keep ones head, you either went with the flow or paid the price of treason.  Of course, every faction could be praying to God at the same battle for victory, believing they were the chosen and only one anointed to rule. However, you never really get to know what God thinks about it all.

The White Queen is another entertaining look into one portion of history, which made me grab for my reference book regarding the real story of kings and queens in England. The series is a great binge watch for anyone who wants to get swept away into the world of dukes, earls, princes, kings, and queens. It contains just the right amount of intrigue to keep audiences tuning in to the next episode.

As far as the cast, they do a plausible and fairly convincing job in their roles.  Every time I see James Frain play another scoundrel in the realm of royalty, I find him convincingly irritating to say the least. Of course, he usually loses his life in one way or the other.

All in all, the series is good. I don't think it is as well as The Tudors, but its right up there with it.  Id give the show four crowns rather than four stars.

This is an impressive adaptation of Philippa Gregory's novels: "The White Queen, The Red Queen", and "The Kingmaker's Daughter". It is true to the books and captures the spirit of Gregory's writing. The series is well cast for the most part, especially the actress playing the central character, Elizabeth Woodville. The series offers fascinating and dramatic storylines based on real historical events of 15th century Britain and the War of the Roses. It is also aesthetically beautiful.

Jennifer Leigh Wells
Author of "Knight of the Purple Ribbon"

As a period costume drama it's about average.
It is a very condensed (and some would say highly biased) history of The War of the Roses.
I wouldn't bother to buy the series (was watching it for free on my prime trial)because it isn't something that I would care to watch a second time.

Problems I had with it:
As a costume geek, I have to groan about the liberties taken. Hey, I know it's on a budget, and I know that they aren't striving for 100% (or even 85%) accuracy, but ...ok. If I look at it the say way as I approach say, The Tudors or The Borgias I can swallow it.

The way the time compacts and expands throughout the series is something that bothered me.

You can spot some of the obviously modern day features in the sets & backgrounds (I'm nitpicky).

Total disregard for the fact that Richard III (who is featured in this series as the love interest and husband of Ann(e) Neville) has a severe case of scoliosis--but hey, it's a costume drama, and they want the sexy side of drama not the more human side I guess.

The good points:

The acting was fine. No Oscar winning work but good enough.

The comic geek in me I found it funny that several of the episodes were written by Emma Frost. ;)

The books are fantastic and this adaptation was phenomenal: they way the three books were combined in the series was seamless.  The plot, based on the combination of the three novels by P Gregory, and the dialogues were great; the acting is top, and the photography looked almost like Vermeer paintings with careful placing of lights and wonderful environmental props.  The only thing I found disturbing was the apparent lack of ageing of the characters but one has to remember they married as teenagers and when their children are marrying they would have been maybe 35 years old. However, some change in their looks would have been more appropriate.  Otherwise this is a MUST watch and great adaptation of the books.

I started off thinking that season 1 was a definite 5 star show. It had good characters and a great story line. The acting and sets and costumes were well done. But man... pacing. The pacing on this show is bipolar. It focuses on a day and then it's years later. I'd go further into it but I don't want to spoil it for anyone. The other thing is it becomes a really lame drama. At times it made me want to hang myself. I literally had to do something while I watched it to keep from screaming.

So right now you're probably like, Okaaaay, then why 4 stars? Great question. In the end, the good outweighs the bad. There were only like three episodes that made me want to kill myself. The rest of the time it was a pretty great show. I think they could have stretched some of the storyline out and saved some of what went on in this season for next but that said, now that they've reached this seemingly dramatic conclusion, I am curious about what they could possibly have up their sleeves for next season.

This is my third time through this series. OK, so it features a zipper or two in the opener (boy, did costumes fix That fast!) and only the old women wear headpieces (perhaps with all the headpieces and hats we wouldn't know which actor is which?). These are problems of a 21st century production for a 21st century audience of a story over 500 years old, and What a Story It Is! These actors bring depth, complexity and humanity to characters that may have, up to now, only appeared in a chapel's stained glass windows or the face of a playing card. The producers also seemed to care that the actors resembled the characters to the extent that we know. Having read the three books the season's based upon may have given me an edge, but the dialogue keeps the viewer well informed as to who is who. Sets and costumes are outstanding (except for a few minor historical glitches). And King Edward's horse -- don't get me started on The Horse! What a scene stealer he is, and I think he knows it!

Considering this series moves through historic events with great speed, this production of Edward IV rise to power is well produced, directed, and written.  The acting is top notch with special kudos to David Oakes as Edward's treacherous brother George and Aneurin Barnard as Richard his loyal brother, later King Richard III.  David Oakes is always wonderful, especially when he's a bit sleazy, power hungry, and just not quite smart enough to get what he wants (note his role as Juan in The Borgia's).  Janet McTeer as Lady Rivers is amazing.  Rebecca Ferguson as the White Queen, perfect. Can't forget James Frain as the Kingmaker.  The list of accomplished actors in this series is endless.  Although I must admit I'm still wondering if Max Irons is really right for the part of Edward IV.  All in all, this series is fun to watch but I do wish they had taken more time to tell the tale, its such a good story.

As someone who is very familiar with the Wars of the Roses and has read a lot about it, both fact and fiction, I found this series extremely weak. Even without reference to historical accuracy and judging it on its own merits - for writing, acting, drama, and production values - it doesn't make the grade. (For what it's worth, I've only skimmed the book and was not very impressed.)

First, the historical inaccuracies. A number of reviewers have commented on anachronisms like zippers and drainpipes, but that bothers me less than taking a period that is crammed with genuine drama and deciding to invent stuff - like having Edward IV personally stab a guy who brings him intelligence of enemy activity. Huh? Never happened - and anyway, that was not Edward's style at all.

Second, the focus on witchcraft - it didn't add anything as far as I'm concerned, and detracted from the idea that Elizabeth was in control of her own destiny. And I must say I think Ms. Gregory should have given credit to Rosemary Hawley Jarman's novel We Speak No Treason, written in 1970 or so, which is much better written than The White Queen and went into all that witchcraft stuff, including the Woodvilles' supposed descent from Melusine.

Third, the cheapness. Seems to me the BBC really pinched pennies on this series. I'm puzzled by reviewers' comments about gorgeous costumes and scenery, because I was struck instead by the thinly populated court scenes, the plainness of the costumes, the way (as someone noted) Edward IV appears several times in the same drab-colored doublet, and the use of chain mail instead of plate armor, which is what they wore in this period (but I guess the producers thought chain mail was sexier, not to mention probably cheaper to reproduce). I watched only a few minutes of The Tudors because I was so put off by the miscasting of Jonathan Rhys-Myers as Henry VIII, but I saw enough to appreciate the beautiful settings and costumes, much more sumptuous and more historically accurate than those in The White Queen.

Fourth, the sex scenes. I agree with all the reviewers who found them to be entirely too much. It's interesting to me how many viewers found this an annoying distraction. Maybe programming executives should take heed and rely less on sex scenes to attract viewers and more on compelling characterization and genuine drama.

Fifth, the character of Elizabeth Woodville/her portrayal by Rebecca Ferguson. This is the weakest link in the series. In fairness, this is partly the writing - Elizabeth is too sweet and wholesome, despite the witchcraft, so she's a dull character to start with. I don't think Ferguson helped, though - she's very bland.

Sixth, the relationship between Edward and Elizabeth. Their love story is poorly developed, implausible, and lacking in dramatic tension. Elizabeth is a tease who doesn't know what she wants, and Edward is a rapist. What's appealing or romantic about that? As then, as the series continues, their relationship becomes overly sentimentalized. Vigorous sex scenes aren't enough to fill this gaping hole.

Seventh, the characters don't age. It's ridiculous. At one point, Edward, having not changed at all since episode one, tells Elizabeth, "We're not young anymore." (A writing tweak would have helped, changing it to "We're not as young as we were." But the writers couldn't even manage that degree of thought.)

As for the casting and characterization of Edward IV, I have mixed feelings. I thought the casting of Max Irons was okay, as Irons meets the bottom-line requirements of being tall and good-looking, which was by no means a given in view of casting directors' often strange decisions. And I thought he played the role decently - in the first scenes with Elizabeth, he conveys a certain cockiness and sexiness very well. One reviewer commented that Irons was too young, yet he was 26 when he played this role, and Edward IV was 22 when he married Elizabeth Woodville. The reason Irons comes across as too young, I think, is that the character in the series is underdeveloped and underwritten, so that Edward comes across more as an immature braggart than as a smart, dynamic leader.

On the plus side, there were some excellent performances - Aneurin Bevan as Richard III (one of the more complex and thus interesting characters in the series), Janet McTeer as Jacquetta Woodville, Faye Marsay as Anne Neville, and David Oakes as Clarence (Oakes definitely fits my idea of George of Clarence).

The biggest plus is that the series seems to have piqued many viewers' interest in the Wars of the Roses (not the Cousins' War, by the way - I'm pretty sure that phrase was invented by Ms. Gregory). But overall, The White Queen fails to make the most of the real drama and larger-than-life characters of this period in favor of sensationalized inventions such as witchcraft, a king who personally stabs messengers, and an incestuous uncle-niece relationship. A missed opportunity.

I had super high hopes for this show. There are some great actors involved and I thought it might be Mists of Avalon meets historical fiction. Wish it would have been better.

Drama, laughed, cried and wanted more.  It's a costume drama so it had me  from the get go. WARNING SPOILER ALERT.  The improbable queen is a young widow living in the country with her mother, father, a zillion brothers and sisters and of course, her two boys. After a ferocious battle (off camera) the young king, who is unquestionably, a hottie rides in with a small contingent near the home of the beautiful lady.  He is also accompanied by a lord, who adds more than his two cents, and has considerable distaste for the young women and her family  who were on the side of the vanquished king.  The new king doesn't want to hear it and he agrees to restore lands taken from his lady fair.  Did I say the widow is young, beautiful and listens to the counsel of her best-friend/mother.

The king is leaving the next morning and the young women (probably with a size 22" waist) meets him at sunrise where he tries to bed her.  It looks more like an intended rape than love-making but the king is used to getting his way with the girls.  She grabs his knife and he says, "it's treason to attack the king."  She being one smart-cookie, takes the knife and puts it to her own throat and says, "I am as brave as any man."
 Meaning she'll really kill herself.  Well he goes off in a huff and says, he never wants to see her again.

Agony on both sides until they meet again and he asks her to marry him.  He is "Mad" for her.
 Mom and the priest who marries them are the only ones who witness the wedding.  The good mother arranges for a cottage where they can consumate their love, marriage and the camera taking in the nuptial bed.  After this blissful union, the king leaves and says, we must keep our union quiet for a while but my love, I will send for you.

The new queen is told by her older brother that the marriage was really a sham.  The king just wanted to bed her.  After all, it was just mom, and the priest who were the wedding witnesses.  It was a ploy to get her in bed. His advisor tells him, he must marry the Queen of France.

Racked with anxiety and fear for her future, she wants to believe her king husband but fears her brother maybe right.  There are several charming  somewhat violent episodes to find out.  I don't know if any of this is historically correct but for me, it didn't matter.

The story line is based on historical fact and is a very interesting take on the struggle for the English throne.  One thing that becomes obvious immediately is that people's thirst for power hasn't changed much over the last few millennia, just the method of achieving their goal.  People are dropping dead faster than a fat man eating free crab legs at an all-you-can-eat restaurant.  Perhaps the most striking feature of this series is the amount of gratuitous nudity and sex.  I'm not sure why the writers felt it necessary to show so many women topless, men's bare butts, and couples copulating.  It really adds nothing to the story line, but it does make this series akin to the soft porn of years past.
