Historically accurate fiction based on the lives of 3 remarkable real women and their families. The series provides insight into how the nobility of their day lived, fought, and died and the intrigue that surrounded their lives. These were brutal and tumultuous times when the future of individuals, families, and nations could depend on who produced the first son who would be rightful heir to the throne.

If you have ever wished you could have lived during the Middle Ages as a highborn nobleman or noblewoman and complain about chivalry being dead, think again. Because, after viewing this series, you might find you are counting yourself lucky to be living in the 21st Century and well removed form the time when the White Queen lived.

The romance of brave knights and fair maidens is not all that it may seem!.

The White Queen combines several of Phillipa Gregory's books into a TV show that is actually quite good and done well.  The actors are good, the costumes seem authentic for this period of time, and the scenes are staged true to the books.  It helps to have the author watching the unfolding of the presentation based on her novels.  Whatever "creative differences" occurred, the TV segments follow pretty closely to the original manuscripts penned by Gregory.  I would recommend both the books for readying and the TV series for watching.

I have enjoyed the series, mostly for the historical perspective it gives. It's interesting that Shakespeare makes Richard of York a rogue, Josephine Tey makes him a misjudged, much maligned, excellent ruler, but here in the movie, Richard is portrayed as originally upright and ready to do right by the young Prince Edward, but then because of Elizabeth's lack of trust in him, he turns away from her and goes for the throne himself. I guess we can't know the "truth" of the matter.

The reason I am only giving this series three stars is because there seems to be a mandatory sex scene in almost every episode. It's boring. It's also the reason I can't recommend it to my daughter, even though it would be good for her to learn English history from this series otherwise. These scenes do nothing FOR the series and do a lot against it, just because they really don't add to the story line and the repetitiveness of them speaks to the lack of innovation of the screen writers--some sort of need to attract a lowly viewer who otherwise can't be drawn in?

Saw the original pilot episode and was intrigued. Then I finally got to watch the rest of the series on Amazon. I am so glad I did. There are some first class performances in this part fantasy, part drama, part historical lesson about the Yorks, who preceded the Tudors on the throne of England. If nothing else it makes one want to read up on British history and see how close it comes to what we know as a factual chronicle. The true focus is on Elizabeth, who wedded King Edward. She had at least ten children with the King of England, two of which were boys -- the same two boys which history tells us were sent to the tower and were never seen again. Did Richard do away with them? There is far too much to go into for a quick review but it's safe to say there is enough intrigue, in-fighting, out-fighting, romance, sex and - yes - even witchcraft to keep an audience's attention. Just don't look for exactitude. This is entertainments, after all. :)

It wasn't the plethora of sex scenes featuring much nudity and scarce plot points, despite the nebulous character list. I'm a fan of midevil England historical dramas. This is not historically accurate. It does raise some interesting historical questions.
Essentially, this is supposedly a retelling of the final acts of the War of the Roses from the female perspective. It depicts the male characters as indecisive and pushed to dastardly acts by the wives and mothers of royalty and nobility. It still fulfills the scheming stereotypes and sticks with the Garden of Eden apple eating notion that woman are behind the world's ills after all.
Plus the plot line that an attempted rape, halted by a suicide threat and throat cutting lead to the overall blissful love match of King Edward and Queen Elizabeth defies human nature. I just kept watching, waiting for the plot to improve or the characters to age. Neither happened.

Good acting and beautiful historical scenery in the series. I believe it was shot in some of the historical palaces around Bruges.  I haven't read the books the series is based on, but I am a scholar in this area, and even though I don't believe in the witchcraft plot line, it does make for interesting story telling, and the plot does follow history fairly well, 60% of so. Further, though I might not buy the witchcraft plot, witchcraft was hinted at with Elizabeth Woodville's mother.
What surprised me, and pleasantly, was the acting: quite strong by all the participants. Richard III was played quite well and I was glad to see that in this story Richard did not have his nephews killed (yes, I am a Ricardian here).  The actor who portrayed the Kingmaker, and he was in "The Tudors" was great as usual, but the two female surprises for me in acting were the actresses who portrayed Elizabeth Woodville and Ann Neville! Both had me believing they were these women, and that is good acting!!

The show kind of starts off slow. It took a while for the main characters to form, but once they did it was amazing.  The sex scenes are a little graphic but most of those occur in the first 3 episodes.  After that they are few and far between.  The story line did become a little hard to follow as it went on.  Mostly because they skipped several years at a time. The few complaints that I have are that Edward did not age at all.  He looked the same, maybe a wee bit chubbier, when he died as when you first see him in Episode 1. In one scene it was him and his children eating together.  He looked the same age as his older daughters. If you are a history buff please do not watch this expecting to see a accurate historical reenactment. It's not.  Not even a little bit. Zippers, modern duct work, rubber  boots, etc.  It drove me bananas but overall this was an great show.

As a huge Phillipa Gregory fan, I was excited to discover amazon offers this series on Prime Instant Video. The main character, Queen Elizabeth Woodville, played by Rebecca Ferguson, somehow goes from being a commoner to marrying a Prince of England. What is miraculous about this situation is that it actually happened hundreds of years ago.

What I think sets this series apart from others is it is told from woman's point of view, unlike the mostly male-driven movies and TV shows common these days. Women will be able to relate to the three main characters: Elizabeth Woodville, Anne Neville, and Margaret Beaufort.

If you are not a history buff, this series may not appeal to you, as it is heavier on historical accuracy and less so on soapy drama.

What is the difference between historical fiction and historical romance? Historical fiction used to involve a created character placed in a realistic setting that had been the subject of great research and then expanded to include fictional renditions of the private life, conversation and inner thoughts of a real person in a real historical setting. .And this movement often gives rise to considerable liberties taken from the historic record in favor of telling a good tale, rather than a factual one.  Historical romance has its heart, not in the history of the past but in the love story that happens to be set there.

Philippa Gregory is a serious researcher. She is also a feminist who likes to focus on female characters in an age when men had all the overt power and women had only their wiles. Gregory has not only the historian's craft, but also the story tellers gift. Being an author who deals with women in times past, she inevitably deals with romance--the activity rather than the genre if you will--in a major way. This makes it a little harder to place where the book behind the series lies on the continuum from one genre to the other.  And not having read it, I'm not aware how close the series hues to the book.

I found the series to be highly entertaining, hence its stars and the episodes to both catch my interest and fly by. I also found the portrayal of the story to be sensationalized--not only in the Starz' versions more explicit sex than the BBC's, but in its emphasis on witchcraft and religious fanaticism as well. Margaret Beaufort for example is portrayed as ludicrously fanatical; it's hard to take her seriously. Yet I imagine that a woman who could manage her estate in the detail she personally did and be the respected founder of two formidable colleges had more to her than one gathers here. I personally hate to be misdirected historically in the name of heightening entertainment value or allure.

I learned a lot of historical facts I was never quite interested enough to try to sort out about lineage and alignment in the war of the cousins, or the war of the roses if you will, from watching this series. But I am not so sure I learned a great deal about the real people at the heart of this story, nor--and this is perhaps the more important point in literature than history--about the truths of human experience, .I did, however, quite enjoy the sheer entertainment this series offered up to me..

For those who revel in anything 'Tudor' this should be a required prequel to anything Henry VIII. The Tudors were the unlikely 'winners' in the war of the Roses...the House of Lancaster vs. the house of York. Edward IV who unseated the unstable Henry VI  a Lancastrian king,  was himself unseated by the notorious Richard III, his own brother who grabbed the throne after Edward's death. Edward's two sons, 'the Princes in the Tower' , his natural heirs disappeared and RIchard himself was killed at Bosworth to see Henry Tudor claim the throne of England. The White Queen is the story of the love affair of Edward IV, his rivalry with his two brothers, Richard and George, the plotting of Henry Tudor's mother Lady Beaufort to maneuver her son to the throne and the intrigue abounding in court life of the 15th century.

There is sterling performances by the main players; Edward, in his virile youth, Elizabeth his commoner wife, her mother Jacquetta and Lord Warrick, the 'kingmaker' who disapproves of Edwards choice of wife. There are also good performances by the daughters of Warrick who become wives to George and Richard, the brothers of Edward. It is an excellent series. Series I ends with the victory of Henry Tudor(father of Henry VIII) at Bosworth, and the death of Richard III, the scheming brother of Edward.

The true, but perhaps dramatized, story of Lady Grey, the commoner wife of King Edward.  Her children are the legendary princes' in the Tower of London that King Richard III, Edward's brother, imprisoned and probably murdered.  Lady Grey's daughters became the mothers or wives of nearly all the Tudor kings that came after the last Plantagenet, Richard III.  A fascinating study in the greed and entitlement of the kings and queens of the time.  Lady Grey did not share their avarice but become enmeshed by having nearly ten children by Edward and having a near masterful sense of survival for her and her children.

I had never known a lot about 15th century history, so I was a newbie to all of the major players except Richard lll. I was fascinated to see the stories of Elizabeth Woodville and Edward IV. The sheer scope of their dramas included all of England and parts of France, Scotland, and Ireland. The distances travelled and the money spent was mind-boggling. The focus, ambition and power of the ruling class was hard to accept and hard to comprehend. As for the production values of the series, Excellent! I highly recommend The White Queen to history buffs and romance fans.

I felt the first episode moved a bit too fast to appreciate the developing relationships (I won't spoil the plot). Later in the series, a few things take a turn for the worse, which left me feeling that this was turning into a Medieval take off of the first Hunger Games. Well, I'm exaggerating a little but I was hoping some of the characters would be more permanent in the series as they were characters you grow to like.

Rebecca Furguson's acting role as queen is just as superb as her beauty. Some of the more sinister character's parts are also played very well. Thus, there's an excellent balance of good and evil that can swing either way in an episode. The scenery is breathtaking, the acting excellent, character development better than usual, and there's no loss for romance. There is nudity, however, so you might want to chase the children out of the room.

Overall, this has become a series I very much enjoy watching.

This is a most enjoyable costume drama, full of love, hate, sex, plots, battles, and death. The settings and costumes are excellent, and the acting, while suitably big, is fine too. Battle scenes are brief and not excessively gory. The characters are solid and consistent, if not subtle. An outstanding character is Lady Margaret Beaufort (played by Amanda Hale), who, with shifting eyes and oral tics, appears tricky as a fox and crazy as a bedbug. The story line is hard to follow unless you are a student of the Wars of the Roses, as every side has people named Richard, Henry, Edward, and Elizabeth, and the crown changes hands as often as a hockey puck. Apparently that's what really went on in the 15th century, but there's no need to worry about the details; just go along with it and enjoy.

I was interested in this series, but held off watching it because of poor reviews from BBC viewers.  The series was a pleasant surprise - the plot, script, and especially acting were very good.  In fact, I was so wrapped up in the plot and wonderful actors that I never noticed clothing zippers, handicap rails on building, or anything like that.  But seriously, can you imagine trying to manage a large production like this and build a custom set, and finely comb all details such as making sure zippers aren't visible - ridiculous!  Looking over a few of the reviews again I noticed that quite a few seemed like malicious jabs at Max Irons and I am not entirely sure why except that a few also mentioned his dad, Jeremy Irons.  It was implied that the actors who played his brothers performed better, but I disagree.  Aneurin Barnard, who I believe is very good actor, did not impress me as much as Max Irons.  Aneurin was melancholy throughout, but it only fit with his character's situation in some of the later episodes.  King Edward was believable in each situation throughout the series, as was George.  Jacquetta, Lady Cecily, Lady Anne, Lady Margaret (so convincing!) were amazing.  Don't be discouraged from watching this series by the BBC viewers.  A+ acting in The White Queen - a hell of a lot better than any of the absolutely terrible acting that I have seen on the BBC!

Keep in mind that Phillippa Gregory wrote these books as historical interpretation and fiction, so if you are looking for a documentary, this is not going to be it, but it is pretty close! Both this film adaptation and the books it is based on are well researched. Phillippa Gregory has a passion and knack for keeping true to the essence of the historical figures she chooses to write about, and her theories of their motives are always well researched and fascinating.
I love this series (both the books and the television adaptations) because it explores these incredible women who truly did propel and forge the dynasties we know throughout English history, delving into their motives, triumphs, sorrows, and exploring the possibilities.
I enjoyed the beautiful costuming, gorgeous sets, fascinating acting and above all, perspective and challenges brought to life.
Well done!

The White Queen has the appearance of a really exciting period piece. The history of the Wars of the Roses is full of enough drama, intrigue, and power dynamics to make a really exciting and fun show. I had high hopes for the representations of Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beaufort, and Anne Neville as powerful female figures working behind the scenes of the male-dominated political landscape. Keeping in mind that I have not read the source material by Phillipa Gregory, the depiction of female characters in this television adaptation was disappointing. I thought the series was really on to something in the first episode or two, but then Woodville was reduced to a witch, Beaufort a crazed religious zealot, and Neville an embittered former pawn of everyone in power above her. At some point, the series began to feel as though the show was mansplaining the real reasons why a woman would have had any power or agency during the 15th century. Argh. Finally, I could not deal with the ridiculous portrayal of Elizabeth of York as a successor to her mother's witchcraft who falls in love with Richard III. NO! NO! NO! NO! NO!

Both pros and cons about this series.

The pros include both well written scenes and actors committed to the quality of the writing.

What seemed cheesy to me were the inauthentic period costumes with their lack of period detail, period ornamentation and more modern finishes... did I see a zipper on a dress worn by Queen Elizabeth?

And with the story line placed in the middle ages, I certainly expected more squalor and less pristine architecture. C'mon people, keeping filth and disease at bay was the order of the day -- which is one of the reasons a large part of the population were cowed into believing the church was all-powerful.

Last, in one of the reviews someone mentioned there were separate versions released -- for UK and US audiences -- with the US version having more sexual content. I for one would have preferred seeing fewer naked backsides and bare breasted women. Some of these scenes felt like they were lifted from a set in Casterly Rock. And Ms. Gregory certainly didn't include that level of detail in her writing.
Best Show EVER!!!! So glad I was able to get it on BluRay, the picture is perfect!

a superb period costume drama that takes many artistic and historical liberties by leaps and bounds but that's what makes it so much fun.

The actors are first rate all the way and my favorite is the Duchess Cecily. She's an absolute scream; the epitome of the mother-in-law from the darkest regions of hell from whom even the devil himself would run. The woman looks like an evil alien from Mars.
She's like a walking, talking, breathing "cold spot" that paranormal investigators are always looking for; well look no further.

And then there's the Lady (Anne) Neville; oh yeah, here's another piece of work. She sees signs and visions and has God on her speed dial LOL!!!
Every lousy daybreak is a sign from The Almighty;  Ingmar Bergman's got nothin' on this one. Man, after awhile it's like, honey you should seriously chill; I wonder what they used for tranquilizers in those days; she definitely could have used some modern meds, that's for sure, but I'm not certain how effective meds are for seriously delusional religious zealots.

There are actors you will recognize from "The Tudors" who are wonderfully gifted actors and so convincing in their roles.

The costumes and jewels are way over the top for that time period, but who cares, it just adds to the visually delightful ambiance of life at court; murder, mayhem, back stabbing, scheming, beheadings and a fair amount of good 'ole fashion witch craft; folks really ran amuck in those days playing musical thrones, back and forth they go; it's a blast.

For those who prefer a more accurate depiction of how life used to be back in the day, they should watch "The Lion in Winter" with Peter O'Toole and Katherine Hepburn running around in soiled rags while they floor the audience with some of the most brilliant dialogue ever conceived.
Unfortunately, there isn't anybody today (IMHO) who can touch either of those legendary actors.

English history was never presented to this degree of resplendent glamour but unless you want to watch a tiresome and snoring boring old film like Richard III with Olivier (God, how many times was I subjected to that horror in high school), then watch these newer iterations of the classics and be truly entertained. lotsa pretty people too of course -:)

I have read Phillipa Gregory's stories, gobbling them up one after another. They satisfy my period history addiction with the bonus of a touch of the authors theories behind the history. I thoroughly enjoyed every one that I have read. That being said, I l loved every episode of The White Queen. I thought all of the characters were brilliantly done, and enjoyed the actors visions of them. The entire series follows the stories it is based on pretty closely. There are always variations to a story when it is made to film, but I didn't feel there was too much happening away from the written stories.  I watched one episode a night and then grieved a little when it was over. Worth watching! I would love to see more of her books into film.

I have to say that I saw some comments about the war being won by men however, the clandestine nature of war can not be ignored.  This was in interesting and captivating series and I am just disappointed that it ends.  I am looking forward to the White Princesses.  I loved the Richard III actor. Amazing series!! I was hooked after the first episode. And now that I finished season one I was frantically searching for season 2 when I now learned there isn't any plans on bringing season two. King Richard dies and it ends how heart broken I am to not be able to watch more. While watching I wa googling and following the history eager to learn about the English and their kingdom. I have started to learn so much about the history. I beg for them to consider bringing back more season,  for it is the history that allows us the need and want to learn. Guess I am forced to read the novels in hopes that more season are coming.

**Edited to add:  Finished the series and it really grew on me as it continued - changed the rating to four stars after all [there were somewhat fewer TV-MA scenes as it went on, as well].  As an adaptation of Phillipa Gregory's versions of these characters and time period, it was very well done.  The particular spin that Gregory put on the characters is accurately shown in this show.  I'm not sure how it would come across to someone who hasn't read the books, or at least one of them, but they've done a great job with the material in this production.  The casting is what really makes it reach its potential.  I've seen the movie made from Gregory's book "The Other Boleyn Girl," and this production is a far superior adaptation in all aspects.

This part of English history can be pretty confusing to follow, with all the tangled up family trees involved, but this series manages to pretty much make it easy to figure out who is who.  Henry Tudor's claim to the throne is hard to understand in the show, but that's because it's hard to understand in the actual history, too; his nearest link to any royal blood came from a French Queen who was the widow of an English King - not exactly making him a shoe-in for the English throne.  His other royal lineage did come from English royalty, but not a direct one and the ancestor from which it came was born out of wedlock. It is an amazingly complicated progression of events that led up to the end of the War of the Roses, so if you feel confused watching this show, that's to be expected, but it doesn't take too much reading to get a grasp of it, if you are interested enough to pursue it.  It's easy for me to like a show like this because I really enjoy English history of this time period; it's fun to imagine the personalities of the real people involved, which is where Gregory's contribution comes in, to create, from names & dates, characters with virtues and vices that make them seem more real.

Original text:
I've only watched one and a half episodes so far, and it's one of those - I should say ANOTHER one of those - shows that would be very watchable were it not for the excessive number of fairly graphic sex scenes.  I've read several of Phillipa Gregory's books, so I know better than to expect true historical accuracy, and don't mind that too much; she writes a good story even if it's stretching and scrambling the truth.

The casting is excellent, costumes and sets are visually pleasing [I loved how they had Elizabeth Woodville in the same plain dress day after day at first - that's how it was for the regular folks in those days], and it's just enjoyable to watch...until about the third time you have to see the main characters grinding away in bed.  I'd have given it 4 stars if not the for all that.  It's sad that Hollywood doesn't think they can interest an audience with just excellent casting and good production.

I didn't realize this was a series about "The King's Grey Mare" until I began watching episode 1 on Prime. So now I am intrigued because Elizabeth Woodville was a fascinating person and kind of a hub for alot of intriguing English history.  Point of detail -the leaping horn on the side saddle is an 1800s development. Elizabeth would have been riding a pillion side saddle with no horn, just a platform for both feet on one side I think. But I'm kind of a stickler for horse-related stuff.

Having read all three novels on which the series is based, and also knowing some basic history of the period, there were no surprises here.  But that's not why a person watches a historical drama is it?

The writers did a very nice job of blending Philippa Gregory's three separate threads into a single series, and the most commendable writing and acting created a Margaret Beaufort I didn't hate.  Her character was much more human than she appeared in any of the novels--still delusional and sanctimonious, but somehow sympathetic.

I read Gregory's novels as a user-friendly way to get a basic historical background on a period before plunging into what always seem to be dry and dusty factual sources, and this series would also serve that purpose.

I am a British history buff, but mainly from the Tudor dynasty, onwards. This series, though it takes dramatic license, does a splendid job breaking down the Wars of the Roses. It is addictive and makes you want to go brush up on that period. It was rather enjoyable to watch the evolution of the characters. For example, Richard, by his makeup and bearing over the course of the episodes, starts out as fresh and friendly youth but eventually comes to resemble the wretched Richard III of legend. Margaret of Beaufort grows from a one-dimensional, bitter and pious woman, to a more sympathetic and even darkly humorous character. The costumes are sumptuous, and the acting is superb. This show is everything that Showtime's "The Tudors" should have been.

Not having read the book, I don't know if it's the book or the TV adaptation that is to blame. But what starts out as a strong drama quickly appears to run out of ideas for plot and character developments in the last episodes. The political intrigues, especially after the death of Edward IV are ham-fisted and transparently crude to the point of being laughable. And character development is largely implausible and clearly written mainly to fit the general historical context of events rather than making any sense. The central literary conceit, of making women the central characters in the story of the War of the Roses, starts out strong, but it seems clear the author's talents were not quite up to the task, especially toward the end.

Which kind of sums up the whole effort; a good try, but not quite up to snuff.

This was quite entertaining. As others have mentioned the first couple of episodes are slow compared to the rest of the season. But the time lapses and drama there-after are riveting. I have read a couple of Philippa Gregory's novels and always find them to be historically on-point, to a degree.

In this series she brings the women to the forefront and explores theories not always recognized by 'common history'. Characters such as Richard III are more romanticized than the accepted history. For instance, we know based on Richard's bones he had sever scoliosis, something not demonstrated in the show. It is theorized Richard, a Prince of the tower and Edward IV son survived, and that too is brought into the fold. Margaret Beaufort's role is quite dramatized based on theories, but the story unfolds so well you can't help but be enthralled.

The White Queen leaves the watcher yearning for more information, posing questions about the historical accuracy and the sources of Philippa's information. It is not to say the show is 100% historically accurate , but instead a demonstration of what could have transpired during the Cousins' War  and the roles these influential women played.

If you're into Tudor History this is a must see.

My problem with programs like this is that a lot of people think they are true. In a broad sense, they are. The details? Not so much.

Having said that, I liked The White Queen and applaud telling the story from the point of view of women. I said to myself as soon as I saw Margaret Beaufort "she was a force of nature" - and she was. Not knowing much about Elizabeth Woodville or Ann Neville, who knows how well they were drawn. I liked the mystery surrounding the Princes in the Tower - except that this program goes way out of its way to suggest the younger (Richard) is spirited away and survives, then does nothing with this historical bombshell. King Richard's dalliance with his niece, Princess Elizabeth (Henry Tudor's future wife) was kind of laughable, but I guess it made sense in terms of the way both parties explained why they participated. I liked Jacquetta Woodville immensely, and was very sad for her daughter Queen Elizabeth when she dies, because the Queen lost her best friend and advisor.

As a junkie of medieval English history, I enjoyed this dramatization of some of the aspects of the Wars of the Roses.  It played a little free and loose with actual history, but not too badly -- was closer to real events than many of the episodes of "The Tudors," for example.  But not nearly as well cast, written, or acted.  Jeremy Irons' son was totally miscast as Edward IV -- came off more like a college athletic jock or frat boy than as the brilliant, ruthless, dominating, yet charismatic character the historical Edward was.  The young actor who played Richard III portrayed him as a nice, likable guy whom events controlled rather than the other way around -- which history tells us was not the case (read Alison Weir's "The Princes in the Tower" for a more accurate exposition of his character and activities).  On the other hand, James Frain was superb as "the kingmaker," and the actress who played Jacquetta stole every scene she was in.  Bottom line: worth seeing, but came up far short in comparison to the other recent period series, "The Tudors," which was brilliantly cast, written, and acted, even though it took even more liberties with actual history.

I am reviewing this with still 2 more episodes remaining. I am growing weary. Initially, I was dazzled by the set and costumes. I enjoyed the love story of Edward and Elizabeth at the start. Then I grew tired of looking constantly at Elizabeth's frowning face and perfect complextion. Oh so many close ups! I do understand obviously that a queen always conducted herself with dignity, and was never some smiley gum-smacking gal. But enough. Fortunately, the series started turning to other characters and close ups. I hate to say, however, that every time Margaret (Henry's mother - so many Margarets!) came on screen, I ran to get a snack. Her sickening piousness and grim expressions were cringeworthy. Ann was another I could not stomach. I did not find her believable in her role at all. I found out that the king was indeed Jeremy Iron's son! Once I found that out, I couldn't stop thinking "that's Jeremy Iron's son." Obviously, that is a personal problem. I did like Elizabeth's mother very much. She is an amazing actress and gave much credibility to this series. Margaret of Anjou was just as good. Another reviewer commented that one needed a Google search in one's hand to get through this. I have to agree. I was looking things up constantly, and growing frustrated because all of the names were the same at the time. When all is said and done, I am a reader. I do not do well with television. So take this review as you will. You may be someone who enjoys the visuals.

This is a great television drama with an intriguing story line, based on Philippa Gregory's historical novels. It's set against the tumult of the Wars of the Roses.

In The White Queen, Philippa Gregory brilliantly evokes the life of a common woman who ascends to royalty by virtue of her beauty. As a young queen, she rises to the demands of her position and fights tenaciously for the survival of her family. Her two sons become the central figures in a mystery that has confounded historians for centuries: the Princes in the Tower whose fate remains unknown to this day.

For those who love English history and are fascinated by detail, accurate costuming and flawless reenactment of history, this is a wonderful work of art. The casting and characterization was marvelous. For those who may feel that Richard III has always been given a bad rap by the Tudor historians, this work pretty much vindicates him or at least shows that there were many other family members near the crown who wanted the two boys in the Tower to be dead; not least of which was Margaret Beaufort.

I do have to admit, that it does help substantially if you are a history buff and familiar with the characters before watching this series, because it can be a tad confusing with so many of the people's names and physical appearances being similar. Also, as was common in the 15th century, people are called sometimes by their actual names, sometimes by their titles, and sometimes by where they were from. For example, George, the brother of Richard III and King Edward IV may be called at different points: George Plantagenet, George of York, the Duke of Clarence, the 1st Earl of Salisbury, or  the 1st Earl of Warwick when his father-in-law before him was also the Earl of Warwick, so it can be a bit confusing.

But over all, as I said, for English history enthusiasts and supporters of Richard III, it is a marvelous series with hours of enjoyment. I learned a lot from it. One always thinks of the powerful men in history, but this work shows that at least during the Wars of the Roses, one must not forget that much of the results and the end result, in particular, were controlled from behind the scenes by some very courageous, determined and very powerful women.

First, I must say that I have read everything ever written by Phillipa Gregory and loved them all, even if the Wideacre trilogy gave me nightmares for a while [ a little too descriptive], so when I learned about the BBC series of The White Queen, I knew I had to see it. It is actually a compilation of several of Gregory's historical novels, The White Queen, The Red Queen, The Kingmakers Daughter, and The Princesses War, which all overlap the same families but with differing viewpoints and heroines. If you can keep all the players straight [which is easier in a TV show with faces to put to the names] it is a vibrant way to picture history and the women who "made the kings" Tudor and York.
This show is amazing. I love it so much!  The actors are amazing, the characters are amazing, and I am so excited to keep watching!!

We've watched quite a few British TV series in the last few years and most of them are quite good (better than the average American fare).  The Tudors (which perhaps should have simply been named Henry VIII), Sherlock, Downton Abbey, The Borgias (well, OK that was a US production), Inspector Moore, and others.  I had high hopes for the White Queen, which is based on a trilogy of novels written by Phillipa Gregory and centered on 3 prominent female figures in the famous "War of the Roses".
History buffs (I can't say I'm a scholar of English history) have nitpicked about how complex issues are condensed into simple choices; characters seem either good or evil and not well-rounded, and of course how many years of history are condensed into what seems a shorter period of time (as was The Tudors, to a high degree).  Or that occasionally you can glimpse something modern in the background.  Those things do not bother me.  The story I think gives a reasonably accurate depiction of events that went on during this time span.  What turned me off was that I started not liking ANY of the characters.  Unlike having a problem with them depicted "good" or "bad", I felt they're all grasping for power in their own way, but none of them seemed any better than the others.  If you don't feel an emotional connection with at least one character, it's hard to like a production.  That's why I left off partway through this one-season series.  If you want to grasp some of the War of the Roses and don't mind that nobody seems very noble in character, then you may enjoy this series.
The US version is prominently flagged by Starz, though it was a joint BBC/Staz production.  It totals 3 DVDs and subtitles are available as well as 11 "special features" on the DVD set.

I just loved this series of The White Queen, just wished that the author would continue the story of Queen Elizabeth and King Henry Tudor. Well acted, well directed and well written it portrays a period of history with all the elements of great storytelling and fork lore. unfortunately, it's a Starz network vehicle so it's demise is already foretold. Like Magic City before it, it will most probably end with this or next season. So make no attachments to it's charm or it's grandeur, for it will disappear as well.

I loved the series on Stars and couldn't wait to own my own copy. The movie was riveting and kept to the story-line of the books which, where wonderfully written.  I would like to see the series continue with The White Princess and remake the Tudor's and include Henry's three children' reign as well as the short reign of Lady Jane.
This movie, The White Queen, Season 1 is superb; great acting, costumes, scenery and dialog.  This move series is well worth watching.
I enjoyed this drama and look forward to season 2.  The costumes and scenery were beautiful, and it was nice to escape from the real world for a while.
Havent had a chance to watch this movie yet But from what I have been told its a must watch
I got lost in the show to much going on for me.i did not like familys going  to kill each otheir.
Fantastic series. Can't wait for next season. Excellent story line and great acting. Lots of sex and violence. If you like Reign you'll love this series.

The White Queen is based on the works of a novelist who is famous for playing fast and (very) loose with the facts. I expected something like The Tudors - soapy fun without much fact checking. On that front it totally delivered. This is a great (almost campy) series with a bucket of magical powers thrown in without much purpose. Because it's a BBC series it expects more familiarity with the characters and the events in their lives than the US audience is likely to have. Because it's wildly inaccurate that's probably a good thing. (If you're getting this for Arthur Darvill, he's only in 2 of the episodes, but any Darvill at all is worth watching)

Bravo Starz!  I have become obsessed with keeping up with the Starz annual line-up.  Every six months without fail they have brought back another period, dazzlingly and painstakingly recreated.  Ok, not so much recreated as embellished upon.  If you loved, "The Borgias, The Tudors, Spartacus (different time period) and Da Vinci's Demons", then you will most likely enjoy this set.

They have taken many liberties historically, but that just makes it more interesting; at the very least for us.  It seems with all of these shows it is always about power and the struggle to keep or take.  The actors are perfectly suited for their character roles.  I have thoroughly enjoyed watching this DVD set at my leisure.  We usually order the Blu-ray versions but this DVD set will suffice.  It looked great on our HD televisions; just missing all of the extras.

I would rather not go into any details regarding the series because it just spoils it for those planning to purchase the set.  If you enjoy historical drama or period pieces then this will be a sure win to add to your collection.  Keep in mind that it reads more like a historical 'novella' ripe with all the romance.  Highly recommend if this is your genre and aren't a stickler for one-hundred percent accuracy.

I'm sure history buffs may quibble about this historicity of this docu-drama, but it's a darned good watch, and that's what I wanted. I have enjoyed it as much as I enjoyed The Tudors and that's saying a lot.

I find the emphasis on the women of the War of The Roses period of English history fascinating. Often history overlooks them or pays them passing reference. However the women of that period were critical to the way history played out.

The series is superbly acted, and beautiful to watch. I think I'll enjoy a second watch.

If you are watching this for historical effect, find something else.  This is fiction based on history and the writers took some liberty.  However, if you enjoyed the mini-series The Tudors, you are going to enjoy this one as well.  Beautiful and authentic costuming and a somewhat realistic view of life during the War of Roses, this was a thoroughly engrossing series.  I recommend you read some of Phillipa Gregory's documentaries since this series was based upon her book of the same title.  Be prepared for some nudity and plenty of violence.  After all, life was not a RenFest and this show does not even attempt to make it seem like it was.
As a lover of English history.  I thought the series while was mostly based on historical fact, the author did take liberal diversions from historical fact.  None the less I loved the series

I recently binge watched all of The Tudors series.  I'll admit, I only started watching it because of Jonathan Rhys-Meyers, but I ended up loving it.  I watched all of the seasons in about a week (while going to work Monday-Friday).  I didn't like The White Queen quite as well, because it didn't to have some slow moments, but it was still quite entertaining.  The costumes are gorgeous with a few "ooh and aah moments!"
I enjoyed reading the books and thought the stories were well presented and portrayed in the video.  The videos held my families interest from starat to finish.

Have read the White Queen, the Red Queen, the White Princess and the Kingmakers Daughters as well as the Other Boleyn Sister.  I loved all of them.  Season 1 of the White Queen was spot on with the book and I enjoyed it very much.

When I heard that The White Queen was being made into a TV series, I was quite excited because I enjoyed the original Philippa Gregory novels immensely. The show will not disappoint Gregory's fans. The cast is exceptional, and the costumes and settings stunning. The story is dramatic and keeps viewers glued to the screen. But is it historically accurate? No way, Jose. This is very much a drama and NOT a documentary, at times closer to Game of Thrones to proper English history. As long as you know this, accept the show for the entertainment it is and have fun!

Commenced storey yesterday. I did have trouble a first as my DVD player was not comparable with the DVD as my is Australia. Now all is ok & I am enjoying the story.

Thank you.

Rosemary

While "The White Queen" takes liberties with historical accuracy, it's enjoyable all the same. I tend to use historical fiction as a fun source of entertainment, many times a show or good book will simply spur my interest to research to learn the true story.

The cast was excellent, and the costuming was great (unlike "Reign" where the costuming is an utter joke). I am always immensely entertained to see James Frain and he did not disappoint with his portrayal of the kingmaker. He was fantastic as always. This was the first time I'd seen Jeremy Irons or Rebecca Ferguson and I thought they were superb as King Edward IV & Elizabeth Woodville. Amanda Hale was wonderfully annoying as the self-righteous Margaret Beaufort.

So if you like a fun & entertaining historical fiction series I would definitely recommend The White Queen.
Enjoyed every episode. A wonderful way to learn about British history. (Doesn't cover the mysterious "Princes in the Tower" story adequately). Looking forward to the sequel.
I loved this series. Sad to see it canceled. I would recommend to see it. Loved the storyline and acting and costumes
Great series, they did a wonderful job correlating it to the book. Some parts were off slightly, but it combined three or four of Gregory's novels into one series. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
On the edge of your seat good! You just cant wait to see the next episode..so addicting, you will ignore everything just to keep watching!
I have watched Three episodes so far and looking forward to the next.  If your one who likes watching movies of this time period I'm sure you will enjoy watching the WHITE QUEEN.

I read Phillipa Gregory's books the minute they come out.  It has been quite some time since I read The White Queen, but it instantly came to life watching this series.  I do hope they will continue.  A wonderful history lesson, well acted and kept true to the book which always is important to me.  Highly recommend this to anyone.

This is the most amazing miniseries. It's based on the books the white queen, red queen, and kingmakers daughter. The miniseries is true to the books and I didn't loose any interest.  Ever.  LOVE this.  If you loved the books you will LOVE this.

The shows early episodes were very full of political intrigue and infighting but as the season carried on and Elizabeth had less of a role the show got fairly bland.  The whole Richard with her daughter thing seemed like a complete waste of time.  Margaret and Richard were the main characters for the last three episodes.
This was an excellent show with a great story and great actors. If you like history, drama, or game of thrones, you will enjoy this show.
If you live in the United States, do not buy this DVD. It comes from Great Britain and it does not play on the DVD players in America. Then you have to pay the postage to send it back!

This film held be spellbound until the very end, although I knew the historical outcome.  It is well acted, the screenplay is excellent, the photography lavish, and the music appropriate.  The White Queen is based on the struggle of three women in 1464, who struggle in the man's world of power and wealth not only to survive but to become Queen of England.  Interestingly enough Elizabeth Woodville, Margeret Beaufort and Ann Neville all have their turn on the ultimate throne.  I would also recommend reading The Women of the War of the Roses by Alicia Carter also sold by Amazon.

Full disclosure: I've only watched the first episode.
I don't have a big problem with the acting, but the casting is disappointing and changes have been made to the story that are unnecessary.
In the books, King Edward is described as a big, strapping man (Chris Hemsworth comes to mind). Max Irons is good looking, but he's slender and pretty - not the manly-man described. I can't buy into this boy as Edward.
Baron Rivers is supposed to adore Jaquetta, but seems mostly annoyed with her.  In the book, when Elizabeth first arrives at court, he instructs her to be 'more royal than royal' to prove they belong there. It seems unlikely they would hug and behave so casually as they do in the show when they are trying to establish themselves among the nobility.
While I don't have an issue with nudity in films, in this show it often comes off as gratuitous.  What is the point of showing Elizabeth's sister in the bath?
I was excited to find the books had been adapted; now I'm just disappointed and am kicking myself for not watching the first episode before buying the entire season (I had a feeling, even as I clicked the Buy button).  I don't know if I can bring myself to watch more.

I've enjoyed this show's first episodes, but as it nears the finale, to what should have been a climax of hate, ambition and vengeance,  it just lost steam and became very vanilla and not convincing.

Let's agree to put aside every thing we know about the real history and forget Shakespeare's "Richard the 3rd" and just go along with the narrative the show provides us, it  still  comes up very short in providing a convincing motives for the main characters to do what they do. Here Richard, Earl of Gloucester, the future king Richard the 3rd, is depicted as an honorable man, a loyal brother and a decent chap generally, so - whatever makes him do all the horrible things he does? Why should he go against his own beloved brother dying wish to secure the throne for his son? Shakespeare gave us a motive - ambition, and created a character who is definitely the inspiration to Kevin spacey's character in "House of card" - a cold blooded villain who will stop at nothing to get what he wants. But this is not the case here, so Richard's action are puzzling and his character just totally flips from righteous to evil out of no where. People whom you saw generally getting along suddenly are at each other's throats without anything major happening.

The focus of the show was to highlight the influence of the WOMEN and how they shaped  the history, but I have to say they failed there as well, as they did not create a single memorable character that can actually make you believe she can influence anyone. The titular character, the white queen, Queen Elizabeth, is indeed very beautiful and sweet so you can buy how her husband  fell for her and married her  despite of his family's objection, but her sweet nature stand in bitter contrast to what you'd expect from a figure in the middle of such a power struggle. She seems to be  a person who'll have a hard time not tipping a sloppy waiter in a restaurant, let alone scheme and plot and advice her husband in real life and death situation. As for her woman adversaries, they are not so well constructed as characters and again it's hard to say what are their reasons for hating her so much. The only one whose motives are well explained is Lady Margaret, and that is because she is simply raving mad, and super annoying.

It was a disappointment, because it could have been so much more. It's like a poor man's "game of thrones", which is a darn shame, considering GRR Martin whole inspiration for his story of came from this  cruel and bloody piece of history. I enjoyed the beautiful costumes, there were a few attractive actors and the love story between the King and queen is touching, but as a drama it just did not work.

We watched the whole series but it became a bit of a joke with the lack of extras.  The king of England was being
married and there were just a handful of actors representing the noblemen of England.  When the king was sick a couple strolling by in the hallway were able to hear what was going on in his royal chamber.  When they were riding to war I was half-expecting them
to start clicking coconut shells together in lieu of horses.  Diverting if you take it tongue in cheek.

"The White Queen - Season One"
. . . .

Just looking at the cover art, I didn't have high hopes for this series: it obviously seemed like a "Game Of Thrones" wannabee or a trashy historical bodice-ripper like "The Tudors" turned out to be.  But, oh, what a pleasant surprise "The White Queen" proved to be. This series expertly presents the insanely complex political machinations of the War Of The Roses, as seen through the template of the marriage of Edward IV and his queen, Elizabeth Woodville. Edward's relatively long reign set the stage for the infamous drama of Richard The Third, Edward's brother who basically stole the throne after his death, and whose defeat at the Battle Of Bosworth marked a decisive end to the war for the crown.

The characters in this series are vivid and compelling, the scripts are intelligent and suspenseful, and the acting is generally superlative. The largely sympathetic portrayal of Richard is a welcome change of pace from Shakespeare's well-known villainous caricature and other characters similarly emerge as flawed yet fascinating figures, and all of them believable and multi-faceted. The series is remarkably good on the history -- accurate (though opinionated) up through the drama of "the Princes in the Tower," where there is no solid historical record to draw on... This is an excellent entry to the genre of historical fiction about the English monarchy, and is very rewarding both as fact and as fiction.

Sitting down to binge-watch this series with a good rack of mutton, an open cask of wine and Wikipedia's English history articles available when you need them is an experience not to be missed! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue film reviews

I absolutely loved this series and was sad when I finished my discs. Knowing how the stories unfolds didn't change how much I enjoyed watching it. I have read some of Philippa Gregory's works but she has not been my most favorite author but now I may have to re-introduce myself to her work.

Let's just say to take the premise of the War of the Roses, and make a miniseries based on the overall history and players, but containing little accuracy of events and interactions.  That about sums it up.

As a fan of historical fiction, I can get behind a bit of loose accuracy.  Even fans of the Shakespeare 'histories' understand that there is little true historical accuracy beyond the broad description of events.  And I am a fan of Shakespeare's histories!

So dropping the accuracy guideline, this is an outstanding series, though something keeps it from being quite five stars.  The acting is overall very good, but the actual story chugs at times.  I surmise that my hesitation of a five star rating comes from comparing it to other series in a similar vein.

One huge plus: the costumes and setting are very well done for the time.  Viewers should watch the series if for nothing more than that!
I loved this series. It was well-acted and the fact it was based on history really was impressive.  Well done!
This DVD covers a very critical part of English history which is almost unknown to most people except for Shakespeare's plays.

I found this series to be very faithful to the novel "The White Queen," the first of Ms Gregory's series on the War of the Roses. It is told from the point of view of the women, and in this series two women in particular --- Elizabeth Woodville, Queen of England (Rebecca Ferguson), and Margaret Beaufort (Amanda Hale), the mother of Henry VII. Those who criticize the program due to some historical inaccuracies are, in my opinion, missing the point -- neither the series, or the books upon which it based, are suppose to be history lessons, but rather are entertainment based upon historical events. Anyone who has read Ms Gregory's Tudor novels knows that she puts a particular spin of her own upon historical figures...from whether Catherine of Aragon and Prince Arthur consummated their marriage to whether Elizabeth I could rightly be termed the Virgin Queen. If historical accuracy trumps what is meant as pure entertainment, then this may not be the series for you.

It is my understanding that the first season of The White Queen is also going to be the last season. It was, from what I have been able to research on the Internet, a two season program that was not renewed after the first season. I think that is a shame, as the first season was quite well done in my opinion. The cast is excellent, especially James Frain as Warwick the King Maker (and I am glad that his hair covers his ears, as they can be distracting). It is difficult to recreate battle scenes on the small screen, but I think there were enough that the viewer had a good perspective on what actually happened. I, too, noticed the presence of a zipper in one shot when the perspective queen was viewed from the back -- that was very careless on the part of the costume designer, as this is not live television where anything could happen. I did not see that repeated in later scenes. The love story of Elizabeth Woodville and Edward IV (the handsome and talented Max Irons) was quite well done -- the beautiful couple of their day. Rebecca Ferguson was absolutely gorgeous and a very expressive actress. I am glad to have this miniseries as part of my personal DVD library will no doubt watch it again and again. For the purists among us, just remember that these events took place almost 600 years ago, and over time facts become distorted. As director John Ford once said, sometimes "you print the legend."

I love the series but I'm having trouble following all the battles and who is who.  It's hard to know who are the good guys and the bad guys at times.  It is very realistic showing the actors breath while in the castles - showing that they are very cold inside.
I love the book behind these shows. Only problem is that some of the story is so sad. Thats history though.
Wonderful scenery, music, and acting. And it even goes along with historical events and facts. Very well done, and a pleasure to watch.
I had read the book and found the film to be accurate on most details as to history of the time and the novel.  The actors were well chosen and portrayed their characters very believable.

I enjoyed this series very much as historical FICTION, although theres part of me that thinks it would benefit someone trying to learn the history of the Wars of the Roses as well. That section of history is so convoluted with people switching sides, friends becoming enemies, brother against brother, etc, that it might be easier to first identify with characters before trying to learn the real history. (But then again, maybe someone interested in the history doesnt need a crash course to get it.)

There are, of course, some parts of the series that are more obviously fiction than others. The witchcraft, for example, although its historical fact that Jacquetta Woodville was tried as a witch, so there is some basis for it. I also, personally, think there was just way too much gratuitous sex. Yeah, I know it was on cable, but still.

I found this series so much more enjoyable than The Tudors. Maybe its because Ive read more nonfiction about the Tudor era so the historical inaccuracies were more grating to me; or maybe I just find the Wars of the Roses stranger than fictionYes, you can make this stuff up, but isn't it crazy to think this is (more or less) how it really happened? Because fiction or not, there is historical fact here.

And yes, I read and loved the Philippa Gregory books (again, as historical FICTION), and was happy that there were much fewer mentions of the goddess Melusina in the show. THANK YOU.

SPECIAL FEATURES: There are a bunch of special features on the DVD, but each is less than 5 minutes and some of the information/interviews overlap. My favorite was the feature about the sets; its awesome how they built the corridors and rooms that could be swapped out for other rooms. Many of the features focus on the importance of the womens role in history.
The White Queen Blue-ray disc was received in good shape. Story was boring and slow at times but over all interesting.
I'm enjoying this series. The guality of the dvd is good. The story line is a little repetitive but enjoyable.

For those who enjoy historical fiction or stories taking place during this time period, you should enjoy The White Queen which is based on the books by Philipa Gregory.  The costumes and scenery look and feel authentic to the time period for the most part, and I found the acting enjoyable.  The series starts off pretty fast-paced through the first few episodes but after that seems to lag a bit, I wish they had spent a little more time on some of the issues that arise throughout the series.  For those who are history buffs or sticklers for detail you will likely have a hard time with this.  When it comes to turning history into a tv series I think it's rather expected that they will forego many and sometimes important details just to make the story more interesting or make the series last longer.  Overall it was a fun series, I'm curious to see if they'll extend it and film another season based on some of the other characters.

This program is out of this world. I like this time period and this season was awesome, the actors and the entire cast did a great job. I can't wait to see what next season brings. Watch this series you won't be disappointed. This series is at the top of my list. I have watched it a few times.

Initially, I should disclose that I am far from an expert on English history, so I'm not in a position to assess the historical accuracy of this series. I'm not so bad that egregious anachronisms would be likely to get by me, but I really don't know much about the history of the various monarchies. Sticklers for historical accuracy should read other reviews to see whether the series will meet their criteria.

I enjoyed the series, so I'll focus first on the parts I like. First, the setting and costumes are excellent. I had no trouble imagining the time period, and the show is lovely to look at. (That said, I suspect that many of the settings were less luxurious in reality than they appear here.) The acting seems across-the-board solid. And certainly, after a slightly slow start, the show has more than enough drama, machinations, and scheming to satisfy people who want drama.

The season kept me entertained, but I don't know that I'll be watching it again. The character of Edward IV was not as compelling as I had hoped, and there was an excess of sex here. I'm not trying to be prudish, but the people who put together this release seemed to believe that it was necessary to stop the action periodically to show more skin. Or maybe there's just something inherently off-putting about seeing a queen naked, as if we are transgressing merely by watching. Either way, I thought the pacing of the show as a whole could have been better.

Although this is a very fictitious version of "The War of the Roses," the acting, costuming and cinematography on The White Queen was fantastic. I can't say I enjoyed this as much as The Tudors or The Borgias and other docu-drama series, but as a mini-series this was entertaining for what it was. I'm not sure why this is being sold as "The White Queen: Season 1" when the packaging states it was a mini-series and I can't imagine what they'd do for a second season, but just know if you HAVEN'T watched this - The White Queen is not getting a second season. It was designed as a ten episode mini-series for the Starz network and that's exactly what you are getting here.

The first three episodes were pretty good and we watched them in a row. The pacing was fast and the storytelling was tight but as the series went on, things really began to drag. it was as if the scriptwriters realized they were going way to fast through "The Cousin's War" novels and had to slow things down and drag things out to meet the ten episode commitment. As such, the pacing dramatically changed and we started to get bored with the series towards the end. We found the series to be worth watching, but it's not something we'd watch again or recommend for owning. Netflix it, rent it or wait for it to come out on streaming.

In general, I love British period pieces, so I jumped at the opportunity to watch and review "The White Queen," even though I'd never heard of it. I should have researched it first.

In the beginning, I found myself intrigued by Elizabeth (who would become the White Queen). I didn't care much for Edward, but I figured he would grow on me. Instead, as the series progressed, I found myself bored--too much talking, too many time jumps, not enough action. Except for bedroom action. Seriously, there is so much sex and nudity in this series! (Apparently, the version that ran on the BBC was much tamer, but the Starz version, which is what the DVD version is, added to the sex and nudity.)

I know many people greatly enjoyed this series, but it wasn't for me.

It was only a matter of time before premium television networks like Starz discovered the drama and pageantry inherent in the great moments of English history. The Wars of the (red and white) Roses, brilliantly dramatized by Shakespeare in several of his history plays, was a conflict between the powerful York and Lancaster houses for control of the crown of England, and was one of the most important struggles in England's illustrious, storied past.

Based on a popular novel by Philippa Gregory, The White Queen recounts a fictionalized version of the political tensions that were the seedbed from which modern England sprung. It is superb drama, regardless of whether or not it is strictly authentic (it isn't). The writing is excellent, the acting brilliant (as is usual for an English production) and the production values and cinematography are stunning to look at.

This series is most definitely worth watching, regardless of the medium you choose. However, if you are able to purchase the Blu-Ray discs rather than the standard definition DVDs, you will find the high-definition version gorgeous to look at and infinitely more engrossing. The beauty and pageantry of late-Medieval England seems to come alive with remarkable vivacity as the intensity of colors, textures and sounds takes a quantum leap upwards. Large screen televisions will appreciate Blu-Ray high-definition images and if you screen your films through a home-theater system, you will find the improved focal accuracy and increased naturalness of high-definition audio to frequently catch your breath, it is that good.

One of the best recent historical-drama series that truly captures much of the great Phillipa Gregory novels of the intrigues of "The War of the Roses"; The White Queen, The Red Queen and The Kingmaker's Daughter.  Well acted, beautifully costumed and with wonderful art direction, the series is a must see for Gregory buffs.
This is an absolutely fabulous series.  I liked it so much that I bought all of the books that it is based on and read them!

I enjoyed this TV series and found that the acting was great and the set superb. Okay, so there are a few historical inaccuracies with the costume etc., but not enough to divert from the overall enjoyment of the show. (Besides, part of the fun can always be spotting such inaccuracies, right?)
I found the series to be a much more tame version of "Game of Thrones"--less action, more talking. If that doesn't sound appealing to you then stay clear of it. Also, if blatant fiction being portrayed as fact will drive you around the twist then I advise you to stay clear of it also. To name but a few; Elizabeth Woodville and her mother are shown to be witches, Anne Neville is portrayed as a harsh and greedy harpy and Margaret Beaufort's piety is shown to such extremes that she comes across as entirely loony. Overall, very dramatized personas that, of course, make for good TV. (And historical fiction too for that matter, which you'll already be familiar with if you've ever read any of Gregory's novels). If you don't enjoy facts being bended in such a way then, again, this really isn't the show for you.
If however you can get past this and are one of those people who can actually watch a show without believing everything you see, then I do recommend the series for it's captivating characters and political intrigue. It's full of mystery and suspense, love and sex, not to mention the tense familial relations that lead to national disaster time and time again. It even has the "who-done-it" aspect of a murder mystery--it's really all in here.
I just hope that if you are not familiar with the War of the Roses/The Cousins War, or the various theories associated with the Princes in the Tower, that you will research them after you've watched the series, and not just take Gregory's word as gospel. Honestly, it's a very interesting period of British history so go investigate and enjoy!!!

My favorite male character in this book is... young Henry Tudor, he is terrific even in the relatively small part he plays.  Queen Elizabeth and Margaret Beaufort are wonderful and they teach us a lot about two formidable women.  The Lady Rivers is a great woman as well, always inspiring and motivating her daughter, and also capable to tell her "It's not about you, it's about England".  Edward IV, though good looking, comes off as very uncharismatic.
It lacks the stellar scenary and acting of Game of Thrones / The Borgias.  However the story line is excellent...

I typically always enjoy historical drama and this series was a good one.  I really didn't know that much about the War of the Roses prior to watching this show.  However, I have read enough historical fiction (particularly that about the English courts) to know that Philippa Gregory writes entertaining novels but takes a lot of creative license in developing her stories.  So while I enjoyed this series, I do not take it as a gospel of what actually happened.  I feel the same way about the series The Tudors- which I also loved, but knowing more about that time period, I was fully aware that some of the story lines were not at all based on fact.  This particular show was, in my opinion, not as well produced as The Tudors and appears to be of a lower budget.  The acting was solid for the most part- I always enjoy James Frain and was glad to see him again.  The witchery of the Woodville women seemed pretty unbelievable on screen.  I have read the book The White Queen and it fit well into the story, but doesn't really translate well from print to TV.  And with the exception of Jasper Tudor, none of the adult characters seemed to age at all even though this story takes place over quite a lengthy time period.  Having addressed some of the shortcomings of this series, I will say that I couldn't stop watching.  It was an enjoyable way to relax and transport my mind into another time. . .I bumped my rating up to 4 stars. . .was thinking it should be 3 1/2, but because I was slightly addicted to watching every episode I decided it deserved a round up to 4.

I'm not a prude by any means but this movie was a bit too much, if you know what I mean. I was looking forward to another of Philippa Gregory's books made into a movie. I've read a lot of her historical fiction books and really enjoy them. For this movie I didn't make it past the first 15-20 minutes of the first of 3 DVD's.  What happened to using imagination instead of having to see women bathing and watch as couples have sex?? Without that "stuff", it probably would've been an amazing series.

The white Queen is a lush, beautiful but painful look at the time when the white Queen lived.
Her King & husband Edward, though loving Her, abandoned Her when She needed Him most. The War
of the Roses is the time where fighting for control of the throne was bloody, especially among family
members.
  I felt the Queen Elizabeth's sorrow, heartache and loss of Her loving husband & child keenly.
The 3 main characters are Women. That is no surprise, since Women hold up the other half of
mortals, men.

Just finished watching The White Queen with my boyfriend and we were quite impressed.  It is well-made and features great acting and sets.  However, this version of events differs significantly from other sources (e.g. Shakespeare's writing and others).  Without wanting to give any spoilers, this focuses on the women of the period and seems at times like a feminist retelling of the story.  Not that this is a bad thing, but the film takes liberties with its attempts to fill in details that don't seem to have historical evidence and uses magic and witchcraft to explain events (and serve as a source of power for the female characters).

Overall, I found it to be very enjoyable.  It is not as glitzy as HBO's The Tutors nor does it have dragons and stars like Game of Thrones, but I found the story very compelling and interesting.
Watched part of it on the free Starz weekend, and got hooked!  Can't wait to see the whole thing.  Love Max Irons!
THE WHITE QUEEN: SEASON 1, IS ONE OF THE BEST SERIES I HAVE EVER WATCHED!  COULDN'T WAIT TO WATCH THE NEXT EPISODE AND CAN'T WAIT FOR SEASON 2!

In person she was seemly, amiable and beauteousAnd according to the interpretation of her name Anne full gracious REQUIESCAT IN PACE.  This refers to Anne Neville, Richard III"s queen.
  The casting of Anne is this series is horrendous. They turn her into an ugly, dowdly frump, wearing the same ugly dress scene after scene. Beauteous. Get it? The author wanted to make Richard a hero, so they uglied up the character of Anne, so he would seem soooo romatic for marrying her. Not buying it. That Richard may have been enamoured with this beautiful girl I can accept. That she was enamoured with him, I cannot. He was a very plain man, and very physically handicapped.
  The stupid sex and nudity is just a distraction. They look like they're jumping each other like dogs. The casting of the other characters was fine. And I found Margaret Beaufort's role riveting. It seems everybody is getting raped in this film. We don't need to see that.
  The story is complex and I have read the history on this extensively.  They make several errors.
1. According to an account Anne, runs away from her evil brother in law and winds up in a bake shop in London, after which she gets a message to her cousin Richard who fetches her and takes to a convent (He left her there for three months to make sure she was not pregnant). This is deleted. Also, the series states that Richard got Anne's money. No, Clarence got all of it. Richard fought hard for her fortune but essentially married her, as they say, in her shift.
2. The series shows Richard showing up at court. shortly before  Edward, his brother, dies. NO. Richard stopped the young Prince of Wales on his journey to London and took custody of him. I don't think Richard even got to the funeral in time.
3. The producer evidently did not like the coifs and caps women wore to cover their hair. All the married women are running around with their hair showing. Women shaved their hairlines and raised their eyebrows and covered all their hair, except for maybe a lovelock.
4. The producer didn't like the men's hairstyles of the time either, which required their version of a styling wand. They all look like boys in some teeny bopper rock band.
5. They all speak modern English which annoyed me very much. They sound like they just came out of my High School.
6. Richard had scoliosis, which is confirmed after finding his grave. The degree was severe. He probably walked with a cane.
This Richard looks fit, and a little cute (Is it Fodo?)

I was pleasantly surprised to find the story so engrossing and well told, and most of the characters were given some interesting dimension.  Unusual with such a large principal cast.
Just the right amount of court intrigue, sensuality, and sumptuous visuals to spice up the historical / fact-based storyline.  The Bruges filming locations were spectacular.  Sometimes these monarchy-themed series don't deliver, but this one did for me.
This show was high on my priority list on my DVR from the first episode. There's a lot of original TV drama on cable right now -  You just can't watch all of it and choices must be made.  I'd definitely tune in to Season 2, if and when Starz produces it.
Love the story. Great acting. Want to see more movies like this. Philippa Gregory is a wonderful story teller. Fun to watch.

Following the current trend in historical fiction, the first season of The White Queen sets the  stage for the great drama of England's War of the Roses (1464). Like Philippa Gregory, Alison Weir and others, the series looks behind the scenes to the women behind the historical figures that dominate England's politics and the warring houses of Lancaster and York, Elizabeth Woodville, commoner wife of Edward IV, Margaret Beaufort, mother of Henry VII and Anne Neville, wife of Richard III.

For those familiar with this fascinating and volatile era in English history, the casting is critical, setting the stage for well-known characters. While I was disappointed with the choice of actress for Woodville, Rebecca Ferguson, the role of her mother, Jacquetta, was perfectly captured by Janet Mc Teer. Pairing Ferguson with Max Irons as Richard IV, produced the required chemistry, but I felt some of the historical detail was sacrificed in favor of romance. However, Amanda Hale portrayed the pious Margaret Beaufort to perfection. Many viewers are inspired by historical dramas to research further, but there is always the risk of mistaking an embellished tale for fact, a traumatic era made more palatable by the attractive leads and their shocking love affair. Beyond the early days with Edward, Woodville was a formidable presence, capable of much mischief and politically sophisticated by the time her daughter, Elizabeth was wed to Henry VII.

 As for cinematography and special effects, I have fewer expectations of Starz when viewing these epic historical dramas. As in the past (the Ken Follett epic), I found the sets less elaborate, the crowds sparser in mob  and combat scenes and the interiors less detailed, a situation perhaps dictated by budget. HBO, in contrast, pulls out all the stops (Game of Thrones), lavishing as much energy on atmosphere as on script and characters, as did Showtime for The Tudors. Aside from issues of historical accuracy, such attention to detail often makes a difference in the visual and emotional impact of the experience (the exception being the staging of classic Shakespeare plays, which require little else but the superior acting they inspire). I thought the costumes in The White Queen were questionable as well, Woodville's daytime frocks much less modest that what the period demanded- though more convenient for secret trysts with Richard. I was hoping for solid history, but often heard the violins of a Regency Romance.

As expected, Special Features round out the DVD, adding context to the history, characterization, and visual challenges of the series: The Making of The White Queen, Series Overview, Book To Series, The History Behind The White Queen, The White Queen: Set Tour, Queen Elizabeth, The King, The Heir Apparent, Woman In A Man's World, Conjuring Up The Queen/Magic, Dressing The Queen/Wardrobe. Will I invest in another season? The jury is still out. Luan Gaines/2014.

If you love historical fiction filled with romance, murder & mystery you are sure to enjoy The White Queen. Once I finished watching Season 1, I couldn't stop thinking about the history of The War of The Roses. I was pleasantly surprised to see that Philippa Gregory has written an entire series: The Cousins' War. The White Queen is the first book in the series. I hope the book is as good (if not better) than the series, as I'm hoping to have a good series to read for a bit! Anyway... back to the Starz series. While it was highly entertaining (my husband & I didn't want to stop watching it) it was also depressing. Seasoned with an incredible amount of scheming, plotting, & revenge with betrayal as the main dish. The innocent & guilty are all fair game to loosing their hearts, heads or both!
