The acting is excellent. The props, costumes & hairstyles, the scenery, battle gear & castles are a stunning compliment to the time period being portrayed. A main character(s) has been left out of the credits... breasts. It would have been a 5 star show if it wasn't cheapened by a plentiful amount of totally unnecessary breast shots. Seriously, a scene would be of one naked breast. The focus of the camera wasn't on the characters faces, just the breast. I actually burst out laughing. It was so ridiculous. I'm not a prude by any means & do not have any issues with nudity. Unfortunately the way it is presented in The White Queen it is completely unnecessary & I feel it cheapened the series. Yes, they are very lovely natural breasts, but is the show about breasts or the crown? Aside from all the lovely breasts, this is a great show & I highly recommend it especially if you are a fan of historical fiction.

I record all the new cable series and for some reason White Queen did not record (my error on the series option).  I was a huge fan of Spartacus on Starz and was excited about the White Queen.  To start out I really know nothing about this historical period so I can not comment on how accurate it is.  What I can say is the plot moved quickley and was interesting, I watched the entire series in one sitting!  It is also nice to have a show with a strong female lead.  All in all the show meets my expectations and I look forward to the next season (this is based on a 3 part book series).

If you enjoyed "The Tudors" you should enjoy "The White Queen".  This has a bit more female oriented twist on exploring the history of England.  A bit of "witchcraft" gives it an intriguing touch.  Overall good acting.  There was only a few minutes in episode 8 or 9 that dragged a bit for me, otherwise I was engaged and very much enjoying the story.
the white queen,seson1is a very interesting and entertaining series. If you like shows that deals with knightsand royal families,than this is it

I love Philippa Gregory.  She has a way with bringing characters to the forefront that are often glanced over throughout history.  She is a true women's writer.  Her female characters show courage, power, authority, love, and sexuality, even though they are set in a time when those characteristics were not proper for a lady.  When I heard that her novels were going to be turned into a miniseries, I was all in.  Lucky for me, this was nothing like the disappoint I felt through The Tudors.

The White Queen is told specifically from the women's point of view.  We see two houses battle for the English throne (the War of the Roses).  Instead of focusing on the battle and the men, we get to see the women's role which was often more subtle.  Each character has her own way of handling things.  Some are very outspoken while others are more manipulative behind the scenes.  The plot line of each episode moves through the schemes and pulls the watcher in.

I was impressed by the actors.  While I tend to believe the women were younger than what they appear to be, they do an excellent job of not being melodramatic.  I found them easy to keep track of, but I did read the novels long before I watched the television show.  I was impressed as my novels came to life.  There are three novels that are portrayed within this series, and the basic plot lines are followed well.  I was impressed that some of my favorite details were clearly visible within the show.

The White Queen is a drama set in the period immediately prior to the Tudor dynasty.  It takes the perspective of three women, Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beaufort and Anne Neville and their quest for power.  The English throne is disputed between two families, the house of York and the house of Lancaster.  The series starts with the house of York's Edward IV being crowned King with the help of a master manipulator and his good friend Lord Warwick, but then the newly crowned King of England falls in love with and marries a beautiful Lancastrian commoner, Elizabeth Woodville, which Lord Warwick opposes.  From there the series is about the power struggles, vengeful retribution and what these three main women will do to gain the crown of England.

The White Queen is a Starz production and as you would expect contains it's fair share of nudity, although the graphic violence is surprisingly kept to a minimum.

For me the series started slowly, introducing you to the characters, background and plots of each of the main characters.  A little too slowly for my liking as it took a couple of episodes and I was almost at the point of stopping watching it, but then it got better and drew you in to the engaging plotline but ultimately tailed off again towards the end of the first series.

Production value seems fairly cheap but most of the acting is quite good but nowhere near the levels of Game of Thrones, which is so much better on every level. In saying that, if you can get past the slow initial couple of episodes this is worth watching.

Whether you know anything about the War of the Roses, most everyone is familiar with the major people involved.  I know it mostly fom the Shakespeare plays.  But like most plays of that period it was from the male point of view Henry V, Richard III etc.

This is the period of Edward IV through Richard III reigns but it is primarily told through the eyes of three women Elizabeth, Edward's Queen, Margaret, mother of Henry VII and Anne Neville, Richard's queen.

While based on fact, there has been some dramatic license taken, especially towards the last few chapters but it is still riviting and well acted.

The entire series runs just under 10 hours and there is about an hour of extras (but these are just promo spots that Starz ran and are very repetitive.)

It was good enought that I would like to see a sequel that takes Elizabeth's daughter, Elizabeth, through her marriage to Henry VII.

Rarely have I seen such a wonderful book to series adaptation as The White Queen.  It's based on three of Philippa Gregory's novels, The White Queen, The Red Queen and The Kingmaker's Daughter.  The acting, the costumes, the script, the cinematography, everything, was done very well.  What will the royal families of England do to claim the crown in the mid-1400's?  Apparently, anything!  Murder, plot, use witchcraft, prayer, seduction, anything to sit on the throne.  For me the standout performance was Amanda Hale as Margaret Beaufort.  She bided her time for years, wishing, hoping, praying and scheming to get her son, Henry Tudor, on the throne.
I had been wanting to see this series. It was everything I hoped it would be. Very intense with lots of twist and turns

I must admit I got caught up in this series much more than I thought I would. I haven't watched the other medieval-themed cable series, but I imagine this one has more in common with "The Tudors" than "Game of Thrones".  This historical drama dramatizes the War of the Roses, when two houses of the same family, the House of York (the "White Rose") and the House of Lancaster (the "Red Rose") battled for the English throne in the 15th Century. The story is based on a novel series by Philippa Gregory, and it focuses effectively on the women's role in all the intrigue, power (or lack thereof) and betrayal of the time.  The acting is uniformly excellent, though as an American viewer, I recognized few of the cast, except the wonderful Janet McTeer as Lady Rivers (Elizabeth's mother) . Amanda Hale is beautiful and captivating as Elizabeth Woodville, a "common country girl" (of a landed gentry family) who is wooed by and marries King Edward IV. She reminds me of a young Gwyneth Paltrow.  James Frain is intense and smoldering as the ruthless "Kingmaker", the Earl of Warwick.  The sets and costumes are impressive and realistic.  Though at times it's hard to figure out who's related to whom and how, and the scheming gets rather elaborate, Though based on historical facts, I'm sure much of it is romanticized - for instance, it's nice to think that Elizabeth and Edward had such a loving marriage, but the truth may be a bit less ideal. Still, it's an engaging series that, at the end, left me wanting more.

First I bought the book series from Amazon, "The Cousins' War."  I had been looking at Phillippa Gregory's books in bookstores for year, but never bought one.  Then when I realized this series of wars, also known as The War of the Roses, was part of my ancestral history in Northumberland, I just had to get them!  I heard that 'The White Queen' had been turned into a tv series, but I hadn't seen it, so I came right back to Amazon to purchase the series on DVD.  I LOVED IT!  My husband watched it with me, and he thought it was a great series, too!  I never shop the bookstores for books or movies, anymore.  I always come to Amazon for the great prices, and speedy delivery to my door!  Thank you, Amazon!!!

Can trace my family back to this time. I thought the love and devotion between Elizabeth and Edward was as it should be, and the relationship with Elizabeth and her family was what families should be.
this show was alot of fun.  From what little i know the history was pretty accurate.  Alot of the scenes were shot in beautiful locations and the cast was very good.

We have watched the first 4 episodes and enjoyed it a lot.  There are some technical problems: on the first disk the episode selection doesn't work so we had to use fast forward to get to the episodes.  On the second disk, the setup option doesn't work so we could not turn on subtitles.  That was frustrating for my husband, who doesn't hear well.  Would like to know if all sets are that way or can I get a replacement that works?  The episodes are good and the costumes are nice.

I didn't know much about King Edward IV or Elizabeth Woodville, but I love how this story is over a long period of time and tells their WHOLE story. Their love is so beautiful and amazing to watch! So worth it! BUY THIS!!! You won't regret it. Really hoping for a season two with The White Princess, Elizabeth of York! She's amazing as well.
I love movie of this time period and I think the acting is great.  I would watch it again and again.

I travel a lot and I am still culling through world history. I have read much on British history and it is wonderful to see the characters come to life. Great job! Shows us again that truth is always much stranger than fiction.

If you like Philippa Gregory books, this is based on Philippa Gregory's The White Queen.  While Philippa Gregory is a capable student of history, some complain about the inaccuracies in this series and her books, but those inaccuracies are probably more interesting to a Doctor of History than an armchair viewer.  These inaccuracies are really more the filling in of things unproven, such as Elizabeth's mother (and Elizabeth) being witches.  There is apparently no proof of this, but it is played in a believable manor for the time.
The War of the Roses was an incredibly confusing time in English history, and if you are not a very serious student of the period, the alliances and hatreds of the period are confusing, conflicting, and changing.  I wouldn't say that after watching this series, you will understand it all, but if you can (could?) follow Years of our Lives, you will follow the action.  Indeed, the characters are human, and being nobles, sometimes more human than you or I.  While all the characters are schemers, some of the evil, they are all people you will relate to.
On the other hand, the production is marvelous.  Costumes and scenery are all eye candy. Acting is not bad.  My biggest complaint is that Edward on his death bed was the same Edward that met Elizabeth under the Oak tree. Edward at this death bed was a bit overweight and no warrior.

I have read "The White Queen", "The Red Queen", "The King Maker's Daughter" and several other Phillippa Greggory books and this series holds true to the historical parts of the book and doesn't "embellish" on the facts to make it more dramatic or "hollywood".

Enjoyed watching the series; my only criticism is the sex scenes, way over the top and not that romantic as portrayed in the books; I enjoyed that it stuck with the story line and incorporating all three books in to one series is a difficult endeavor. I would definitely like to see where the story goes with Henry Tudor now and how history plays out and the Tudors now taking over the reign.
The DVD that you sent was bad, that did not make my day very good, so I did not like the DVD. Roberts
The White Queen: Season 1 was very good from a historical perspective.  The series was done well.  England's stories of kings and queens always interesting.
If you loved the book series like I did, this is fantastic.  The characters are exactly what I pictured when reading.  Love it!
It's amazing!!! I adore The white queen!!! The characters and the costumes and the story lines are perfection! I love this series!!
woo hoo!! i have been waiting to own this after reading all the books and loving all the books by Phillipa Gregory.
I could not view this video.  It is non USA format.  I had no idea that I was ordering a video that I would not be able to watch.

I really enjoyed this series when it aired, and was happy to purchase it. I really didn't know much about the Cousins' Wars before I watched, and now have been interested to learn more about it. It's fiction, and of course will take liberties for entertainment and storytelling, and I'm fine with that. I think it's important for people to know the meaning of the word, "fiction," and not get so worked up about it. If you want to enjoy the series you will.

My main disappointment is the extras. While it gives you a behind the scenes look, for a 10-hour series, I'd expect at least an hour behind the scenes...it gives you a little over three minutes. And while it talks about other aspects, such as some characters (not all which is a little disappointing since I found that there were more interesting characters besides Elizabeth Woodville) I felt it could have shown more.
We read all of the books. Therefore, the subject matter was very interesting. We had difficulty in understanding the actors.

Being a true lover of Englands history of monarchs, this series is expectional.....and looking at the power struggles with the strong woman is refreshing.  The performances are first rate, from casting to filming an excellent, spellbinding series.
I look forward to the new season following these powerful woman behind the monarchs. Highly recommend this !

Love owning it on DVD! Great, although fictious story. I enjoy stories that take place in this era.
Loved the White Queen, hope they also make the Red Queen.
Definitely a great show with twist in every episode. If you liked the Tudors you will find this show equally as good.

I rented this show because I'm hooked on Game of Thrones but I'm waiting for the next season to be released. I like several books written by Philipa Gregory so I thought I'd give this show a chance. I liked it. It was ok. It didn't grab me and the cast doesn't have any stand-out characters but I may try one more episode to see if I can get into it more. If you like this era then I would say it's at least worth checking out.

While I am not familiar with Phillipa Gregory's novels, I took a chance on this series because of my interest  in this moment in history. I was hoping for something along the lines of "Vikings"----- a balanced mix of drama & action. But this is more like Downton Abbey in tights, heavy on the romance while all the action (the battles, anyway) takes place off-camera. This is definitely aimed at a female audience The political situation at the end of the Wars of the Roses was extremely complicated , but it seemed to be over-simplified, at least as it was presented in the first episode. I may or may not  take a chance on the second episode, to see if the aura of Romance sets the tone of the entire series.

They should have just made a mini series of one novel, The White Queen, rather than try to cram three novels together.  There is so much going on, so many characters, they can't do any character or storyline justice.  There are a lot of interesting characters played by good actors here, so it's a shame to see them wasted.  The Wars of the Roses were complex and even though I am familiar with the era and the people involved, I found this hard to follow.  They were layering true history with historical fiction (the mini series is LESS factually accurate than WQ or The Kingmaker's Daughter) and supernatural elements.  Way too many ingredients in the soup. That said, if you enjoy period pieces and intelligent performances you may enjoy much of this mini series.  I don't agree with the casting of the bland actor who plays Edward IV, one of the handsomest and most charismatic kings in English history, but everyone else is very good.
Not game of throne but good enough. Production design is good and the story is interesting. a lot of political moves. I think it's worth it if you like period pieces.

4 Stars is basically for the quality of the production, a well done film. The actors bring a period of history to life that was both complex and violent. Beyond that there were several artistic liberties taken concerning the actual events and the lives of the characters. The real life characters and story were strange enough as it really happened. No matter what one might think it all culminated in the Tudor dynasty and ultimately a very great Queen; apparently named after her grandmother.
True to the book, excellent cast, entertaining and historical. I was impatiently waiting for this mini-series and was not disappointed!
This show is just great! The books are even better! I would definitely recommend you buy the season! Hope you enjoy!

I power watched the DVD episodes because it is a great story and easier to keep track of who's who. It is the much watch series of the year for those who enjoy historical fiction. I am sure there was some license taken with historical accuracy but I do think it was realistically portrayed.  It is interesting in the way that sexuality had a great deal to do with how history is affected by it and how love and lust can change decisions that affect the aristocracy and the people who must have allegiance to them. The White Queen is smart in her rise to the throne, though it is her mother who is the smartest of all. In a time of deception, chaos and death, love can exist, though not so much in a time of war. Power is the ultimate gain and the end game is to be the ruler.

this was just an okay show. it lacked the holding power of some shows i have watched. it didn't make me wait for the next one. it was more a way to kill some time watching something. kind of disappointed after seeing it advertised.

Rent this movie, don't buy it.

It has none of the production values or plot lines like The Tudors.

Also, they show none of the great battles that King Edward fought.  He goes off to battle, and comes back and tells his wife he won.  She hugs him. What few battles there are, the director only shows about 30 men fighting.  What about that one great battle where 20,000 fought?  Has this director never heard of computer graphics?

Also, the number of betrayals makes the Kings appear stupid. Not a single king in this "historic" drama covers their ass.

But, if you like T & A, this series has it with the White Queen.
History somewhat tweaked, but it was a wonderful series, lively and well-acted with great production values. The woman who plays Elizabeth Woodville looks exactly like Ingrid Bergman!
I gave this series a 5 star because it was very intense from the moment it started and I very much enjoyed it.  I cannot wait to get the next season!!!

Loved this when released on TV and so proud to have in my collection to watch whenever I want! Brings the period so alive to me and made me want to read entire series of books by Phillipa Gregory and I did!!!!

As a long time student of the time period I looked forward to watching  Phillipa Gregorys Cousins War series on DVD.  Because there are so many aspects of this period that are left to us as mysteries, I don't have a problem with poetic license being used to explain them.

I thoroughly enjoyed the first six episodes (even if there was some Hollywood license taken), but found the last four episodes to be so historically compromised that I almost stopped watching it a few times.  I could see no other reason to suddenly deviate from the books and history except for budget constraints.  It certainly weakened an otherwise historically accurate miniseries.  Of course most of these inaccuracies are not going to be known by people who have not studied the era and I would not dissuade someone from watching because of them.  I would urge anyone who enjoys the series to do some additional reading of this fascinating period of English history.

I hope STARZ does indeed make a series of Gregorys The White Princess wherein the story of Perkin Warbeck/Richard, Duke of York (the youngest Prince in The Tower) is told; along with the story of Elizabeth and Henry Tudor.

 All that aside, I loved the sets and costuming and felt that for the most part the actors were great picks for their characters.  Amanda Hale as Margaret Beaufort was exceptional.  I had often wondered what actor today could play Richard of Gloucester (later Richard III) and found that Aneurein Barnard was a great pick.  Only Max Irons as Edward IV seemed a little weak.  Edward was 64, handsome and imposing.  However, I do feel that Irons, although not the physical depiction of Edward, played the kings character very well.

Even with the historical problems (I found it much better than The Tudors) I plan on buying the BluRay set for my library.  It will give me my visual fix for this period that I have found so fascinating for 40 years.
Great story, takes liberties with history but still a great watch.  Can't wait for season 2 to start in the fall.
The best story . Followed the books of the author . Love all of Phillipa Gregory's work and the casting for the movie was perfect!

I absolutely loved the series and wanted a copy of my own to watch again and again. I just want to warn anyone who buys the DVD. I ordered it back in September and received it in early February. I played it on one of my 5 DVD players and it started to skip and stop playing shortly after Episode 3 started. I returned it. I received another copy and I played it on another DVD player and it stopped playing shortly after Episode 4 started. Not only did it stop playing, it shut down my player. I called customer service and was disconnected. I called again and complained without much sympathy -- only to suggest refunding my money or replacing the DVD. I opted for another replacement but additionally asked that they investigate the quality of the DVD and asked if anyone else had any issues with the quality. That suggestion wasn't met with any enthusiasm -- again I could return for either a replacement or refund. In the meantime I received an email saying that they wanted to make it "right" and shipped me a replacement at no extra charge (there wouldn't have been any extra charge anyway) and next day shipping at no extra charge.

I received the replacement DVD and played it. Again, it stopped and shut down my player shortly after Episode 4 started. I played it on another DVD player -- this one a player/TV combo. It didn't stop at Episode 4 -- it played the complete episode. However, when I turned on the TV shortly afterwards, the system wouldn't start -- even after several attempts. I'm not sure if the DVD broke my system; I can't make that claim until after I send it off for repair. But, I am reluctant/scared to play it on any other player. I'm not calling Amazon about it; it's just not worth it. Instead I plan on contacting Starz. I'm anxiously waiting for the Outlander series and will be buying that DVD when available. I can only hope that that another DVD from a STARZ production will not be defective.

This doesn't mean that I won't buy from Amazon again; I can't blame them for the DVD being defective -- I can blame them and be disappointed that they wouldn't investigate my claim.

Most of the wonderful "royals" like Tudors, Game of Thrones and others tend to play up the King. Not with this mini-series they gave us the power of perspective on the power behind the throne. Well acted, good imagery and a pretty good story line.

Would not work......not in US format...... was not aware of this prior to opening the package and trying to view the movie.....I need to return the item for full credit or receive another White Queen Series in US Format,  however I understand I will not receive full credit because the package was opened.  Your return policy was difficult to understand.
I love a good period soap opera and this does not disappoint. If you enjoyed Tudors this will meet your expectations.
Beautiful cinematography.  The show is extreely close to the original text of Philippa Gregorys novel, The White Queen. Loved it lots.

I read all the books in the Phillipa Gregory Cousins War or War of the Roses series.  I was very impressed with how she mixed historic fact and fiction.  The miniserious had a few differences from the books.  The ending was changed up a tiny bit and some scenes were added that were not in the books but all and all it was enjoyable to watch.  As a student of history I couldn't give it five stars only because I think it makes some assumptions that are wrong but those also go back to the books.  I don't think Henry or his mother had anything to do with the deaths of the princes in the tower.  Again just my opinion and none of us will ever know for certain.  I just feel it was more of a step Richard or Buckingham would have take verses the Tudor camp.  I also think Elizabeth (the white princess) was less in love with Richard than written and based on a few biographies I've read on her she seems to have had a happy marriage with Henry Tudor.  If she did let Richard court her I think it was more of her mothers idea then hers and as a princess raised to marry whom she was told to she would have gone along with whatever was best for her family.
If you like historical drama's then you'll love this one. It turned out to be a pleasant surprise and very entertaining.

If you love period pieces, you will love the white queen. It has all the elements a good show should have: intrigue, betrayal, love and lust, greed, and witchcraft, just to name a few. It is very entertaining.

Pretty good production value and overall very enjoyable for fans of medieval English drama. Costumes and sets are beautiful and the acting is solid. Overall focus on the female characters is refreshing and done quite well. Slightly different from the version that aired on the BBC (more R-rated).

I'm a sucker for well-made costume dramas, especially those about the history of British kings and queens. And this series was very well made, with detailed but not unrealistically lavish sets and costumes, a very fine cast including some old favorites and some newer faces, and a very human story of family as well as kingdom. It inspired me to purchase the books it was based on, and I've begun reading them.

Nothing was sanitized in this production. When it's cold in Britain, you see the actors' breath -- both inside and outside their homes. You feel the slipperiness of mud and blood at battle sites. You feel the fabrics and smell the smells -- no wonder people died of fevers with such regularity.

The major characters evolve through time as they must have in real life, and you find yourself loving and then hating them, wishing you could shake them and tell them what they're planning will backfire.

All hallmarks of a well-made series and a well-told story, But it ends precipitously, and England has no real king. Well, after all, I guess that's how it was at that time and in that place. Worth watching.
White Queen is addictive and so well cast.  Great story line...and we don't want it to end...but alas it will.

Found this series a good insight into the danger of being royalty in that time period.  Since I am a huge Tudor history fan, this was right on the money for me.  Even though women were considered property back then, it shows the power they really had.  My favorite series next to "The Tudora"!

I came in REALLY wanting to like this, but it was super disappointing. It's very heavy on telling not showing. Now I get that to an extent: there's no way a TV show can put together movie-like grand battle scenes, and that's ok. The problem is that there's no real tension between episodes and even scenes--stuff happens off screen, you're told about it, and you move on.

The acting is so-so. Yes, all of them are pretty, but aside from a few exceptions, I really didn't find myself investing in any of the characters. James Frain is always enjoyable, and the actress playing Margaret Beaufort did a nice job too. Edward, the Lancastrian prince was creepy good, but he got so little screen time that it really didn't matter.

As a whole though, everything feels super rushed and underdeveloped. Calling it the "poor man's Game of Thrones" is giving it too much credit.
I loved the books and the movie lives up to the books. This portrays the war of the roses from a woman's point of view.
Great and flawless acting by the entire cast. Loved the costume designs. I have not come across a series like this in years.

I have read most of Phillipa Gregory's historical fictions and enjoyed them.  They are entertaining, well-researched and woven into  very credible stories.  I've seen many of the work put into shows and movies.  I'm a big fan.  However, this series disappoint.  The writing is shallow and predictable.  The costumes are great and the scenes are fantastic.  But so many gratuitous sex scenes and so poorly done.  Pornographic, but heavily biased towards showing just the women naked.  Is this an attempt to attract male viewers?  Really, those guys may just enjoy plain pornography.  Edward of York is portrayed as a handsome, dumb sex-fiend and his deathbed scene is overwrought.  Most of the characters are single dimensional, and does not do justice to the original characters developed by the Gregory.

Was so frustrated buy the time it arrived had a bad taste in my mouth for it, lots of blood an guts , power struggles, etc
but good sets and acting is fine.

I have watched a lot of the period dramas- Reign, The Borgias (both of them), and The Tudors. This one is even better than The Tudors, which was my favorite. The White Queen is EXCELLENT! I am hoping there will be a Season 2.
I am not a big fan of period pieces, but this series held my attention.  The main character, Queen Elizabeth, did a great job.  Would like to see her in other movies/shows.
This is a compelling, exciting story, well acted and depth given to the characters but the raw nudity distracts rather than adds to the overall storyline.
is that the three female protaganists are all sort of unlikeable, especially as the series continues. It's worth watching though

This was a fairly good and watchable series, but covers such a broad span from 1464 to 1485 that some of the important events are shrunk into a crush of minutes and episodes.  The battle scenes in particular had so few extras and little attention to the size and scope of what was actually happening that they probably should have been excluded altogether and simply mentioned in dialogue.  Why the technology of animation for mass battle scenes could not have been employed here may have been dictated by a limited budget.  It is unfortunate. The more sumptuous court and ceremonial scenes were shot in Bruges or Ghent and are worthy.  Most of the acting is actually quite good and what may be the only appreciable movie/film depiction of the hard fighting and womanizing King Edward IV is delivered by Max Irons.  I can't recommend this series for its historical accuracy since many of the events and verdicts remain shrouded in mystery and conjecture, but will say that it can offer good entertainment for history buffs who may wish to embark upon further research.
I really like it because I am a big fan of British historic movies. Full of excitement !!! Good to know more seasons are coming..

Even though the streets and the characters were clean (never the case at the time) and there were several liberties taken with fact, this was quite well done, very entertaining, begged some use of the personal brain in pondering motives and never made me want to take a nap. Even the you-know-what scenes were tastefully done.  Unlike The Tudors, which got the queens in order but otherwise did nothing but stray from the truth and the worst thing ever made, Reign (what was that?) this was worth taking the time to watch.

If you liked "The Tudors" I think you would like this. Not a children's show!
Thank you for the history lesson!

I wish there was more but what WAS in this show was awesome. Very good acting. Loved the story line. Not sure how historically correct it is but I don't let things like that bug me. It's Hollywood. The show makes you want to know more. I'm glad it's based off a book series so I can read what I want to know.
Love it! Great historical drama with a great depiction of the war of the roses! Worth your time and attention!

For those history buffs this production is just the ticket.  After this season's viewing I had to do some research to see how much of the story was true.  The costumes, writing and acting were flawless.
If,you like period shows you'll love this!  Not as beautiful as the Tudor's but it is earlier. Love strong women
great dvd wonderful service!! I loved the story lines and can't wait for the new season to become available!! a definite must buy!

This drama is based upon three central women during the War of the Roses. While the various dramatic scenes come from the imagination of the writers, the basic story, the characters and their actions are true to history. The action and machinations of the characters will keep you watching to see what happens next, and maybe even referring to a history book to confirm that what happened was really true.
I couldn't get through the first episode.  A shallow plot, poor historical costuming, and so-so dialogue made this a boring show.
Enjoyed the plot and the action.  Loved the costuming.  Characters to both love and hate.  What more could you ask for?
Recommend to anyone who likes History, especially British History. The acting is first rate and it's an overall excellent experience.
It was so good I couldn't just watch it once. There were so many of my relatives that I found on ancestry.com in the story.

This dvd had a great story line.  However, there was too much nudity and disgusting sex scenes.  That does not need to be in movies.  That is why I refuse to keep the dvd and will give it away.  I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone.  It should have had a stronger rating than not rated.
Very enjoyable!  Might not be historically accurate, but fun watch! The set and surroundings were beautiful, would love to see them in person!

The DVD was not compatible with my blue ray player.  I never heard of the player it kept saying I needed to use.  Therefore it was useless.

I definitely would not recommend since I was never able to use it.

The actors were splendid.  I especially liked Margaret Beaufort (Amanda Hale).  She was so convincing as Henry Tudor's mother. Watching this really explains (to me) the complicated and dangerous period of the York Reign. I really hope that this series is continued!
Fantasti! Well acted, beautiful costumes, drama and political intrigue; similar in genre to Game of Thrones but from a woman's perspective!

Good mini-series based on historical info.  Excellent show but limits further seasons unless the primary focus changes to the newer characters as the series would progress over time.  Kind of an abrupt end.  Would have liked to have seen a resolution on what happened to the prince and the stand-in jailed in the tower.

Great take on the War of the Roses period from the perspective of the women involved.  Especially love Jacquetta, who managed to successfully maneuver through two opposing English courts, as well as the courts of Luxembourg and France.
Over-edited. Loose storyline compared to novels. Assumes viewer has read the books. Cinematography good which makes the show worth watching.

This is a well made series about the war of the roses.  but as it goes on it deviates from known history to a big degree.  The biggest deviation is having margoret tudor plot the death of the princes in the tower.  She in fact , couldn't have done it. That doesn't mean if they were still alive that henry tudor wouldn't have had them killed when he won though!.  But  they were long dead , before the Bosworth.  It does present Richard as a good king though, which is was, he was NO tyrant. and he could have gone done as a great king if he hadn't done away with his nephews. This also has him sleep with his niece. which didn't happen as she was  virgin when she married henry tudor ! ,  History is actually NOT boring, and doesn't need these type of changes to get viewers.  The story of the white queen is told from her side mainly. And it's engaging and sort of true. except she wasn't a witch , and no one ever thought she was. This will entertain you, but it's far  from history on some points obviously.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this series!!!!  Can not stop watching!  Highly recommended.  Great acting, and love the costumes, and scenery.  I have read most of Philippa Gregorys books, so was excited to see this series.

The comedy is very low-key, to the point initially of being almost boring, but by the end of the show (before Tambor's big reveal)
I was addicted. The writing, acting and directing are all top-of-the-class.
I came upon this DVD by accident and I am glad I did.  Very well done series.  Hours of wonderful TV.
Bought this for a friend and they loved it! This has to be one of the best series Starz has produced.
Amazing series. Never knew the ways to power were so deadly. How quickly you and your family could become in danger.

This is a beautifully produced series, but I wish it had been more historically accurate.  With The War of the Roses so thoroughly researched through primary sources, I'm disappointed with the many historical mistakes or misrepresentations. Why this must be done I will never know.  This is such an amazing story to begin with, why change it for dramatic purposes?
If you loved The Tudors you'll certainly love this!!! I got addicted to this. I hope they make another season.

I really enjoyed this mini series when I saw it on Starz. I knew right away that I wanted it in my library of historical dvd's
The actors were great and the story was wonderful.  thank you and I sure wished they continued with the saga.
I read the books and the show is just as good!! Awesome! Totally worth the money and watching. So easy to watch on my I pad also!! I will be purchasing more videos!
we are enjoying the journey this series takes us through the history of England up to the reign of King Henry Tudor.

This was a minseries based on the Phillipa Gregory books, The White Queen, The Red Queen, and The Kingmaker's Daughter.  It was beautifully done, the costumes, the writing and the acting!  I pre-ordered it and have watched it 3 times completely, and never get bored of it.  Kudos to Starz and of course Phillipa Gregory for writing the awesome books!  Hoping that Starz will do The White Princess
The white queen season 1 is a Good show, it's accuracy is questionable but the show is overall entertaining and interesting.
Escapism, drama and history with an edge.  Love the way this story unfolds and highlights the strong women driving the War of the Roses.
I loved this show from the beginning and was so pissed off when I couldn't watch it anymore now I proudly own the entire first season :)
Well acted and intriguing story line. Not clear on the historical accuracy but given the potential plot twists it appears well worth the time to stay with the series and see what unfolds.

I ENJOY STORIES IN THIS ERA.  THE ACTING IS GOOD.  THE SETTING IS AND ALSO THE COSTUMES.  I AM SURE THOSE THAT LIKE ENGLISH HISTORY WOULD ENJOY THIS SERIES.  THE LEAD ACTRESS IS BELIEVABLE.  THE AUTHOR OF THE BOOK THAT THE SERIES IS MADE FROM IS WELL KNOWN AND HER BOOKS ARE VERY ENJOYABLE.
I really enjoyed the visuals and dialogue if the history wasn't always spot on. The casting was perfect; everyone looked just like the were brought to life from their portraits.
Great historical series covering England's War of The Rose. If you like Philippa Gregory's historical fiction, you'll love The White Queen.

THERES A WHOLE lot of history going on in this 10 episode story of Great Britains Wars of the Roses (1455-1487) and it all looks wonderful in glorious HD Blu-ray.

Produced by the BBC and Starz, and filmed on location in Bruges, Belgium, its based on Philippa Gregorys series, The Cousins War a.k.a. The Wars of the Roses, providing a fresh look at how family conflict between the Lancasters and the Yorks led to a 30-year war. Most are familiar with the story of Richard III, the crippled hunchback, supposedly responsible for the murder of his two young nephews in the Tower of London. We know the quotes from Shakespeare  Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York (i.e. Edward, his brother, whose symbol was the sun, then sitting on the throne of England).
And we also know Richards end quote, A horse  a horse! My kingdom for a horse!

If you do know the story of the Wars of the Roses and you know it from Shakespeare, you're in for a surprise, says actor James Frain, who plays the Kingmaker, Duke of Warwick. Shakespeare was writing under a Tudor monarchy; he was writing Tudor propaganda.

This big, evil character we know as Richard III in Shakespearean plays wasn't that, explains Aneurin Barnard, who plays the much-maligned Richard, Duke of York. The real Richard III was something quite different.

And so, generally, is everyone else in this action-packed romance, even if George, Duke of Clarence (David Oakes), still drowns in a vat of malmsey (wine). The intrigue here is finding out why.

Our story begins when commoner widow Elizabeth Woodville (Rebecca Ferguson), a Lancaster, and her two young sons confront king-to-be Edward of York (Max Irons, son of Jeremy). The chemistry between these two is immediate  and all but radiates from the screen. Edward has a well-earned rep as a ladies man  Im quick, Im brave, Im as lucky in battle as I am in love  and Elizabeth knows the score; she will not succumb to lust, no matter how tempting, until they are married.

When that happens, Kingmaker cousin Warwick goes berserk; hes been negotiating a huge dowry and land deal with the King of France, to be delivered when Edward marries a French princess. So, when the newly crowned Edward proclaims Elizabeth queen, decisively chucking his cousins applecart down the mountain, Warwick does not take it well. Edward changes the power balance of Europe over night, Frain explains.

We are the three sons of York, Richard declares, exasperated. How can we be divided by one woman?
This is how wars begin. Warwick raises an army and the men of York go to battle, while and the women scheme and plot  using a nasty blast of witchcraft here and there. In the background, a very young Henry Tudor waits to see how it all plays out. His primary task is to stay alive as his mother, the obviously disturbed Margaret Beaufort (Amanda Hale), has told him he will be king  one day.

If the series seems longer than a mere 10 episodes, its because they are so well written and theres so much to absorb. Still, theres no need for a degree in British history; all is well mapped out and the characters are unforgettable. Every actor does a convincing job of making his or her part come alive. Does it make a difference that we know Richard doesn't get his horse or that Henry Tudor succeeds to the throne? Not a jot. This is a fresh telling of an old story, one that many today claim to be more likely than Shakespeares rendition.

The Blu-ray transfer is stunning; I was dazzled by the rich, intense color and magnificent detail. (We can see every freckle on Fergusons beautiful face, every gold bead on her coronation gown. Velvets look plush enough to sink your hands into and Id personally like to walk barefoot through those green meadows.) Location shots are breathtaking, like the cool, birch forest where a battle takes place. Erotic scenes are well-lit and exquisitely shot. (Yes, sex scenes are a matter of taste; these are not for children.) Black levels are lush; exteriors and flesh tones look natural. We can see clouds of frosted breath, both inside and outside the castles. In no film has the chill of a medieval interior been more apparent. An immersive Dolby TrueHD 5.1 soundtrack balances dialogue, score, ambient noise and effects. Everything sounds precise yet natural.

I was disappointed in the extras, however. They boasted great titles: The Making of The White Queen, Series Overview, Book to Series, The History Behind The White Queen, Set Tour, Queen Elizabeth, King Edward IV, The Heir Apparent, Women in a Mans World, Conjuring Up The White Queen, and Dressing the Queen. But they are all promo pieces and only minutes long, with a lack of satisfying, in-depth info  only nuggets here and there. A map and family tree is included in the packaging, as well as a $5 coupon, good till Dec. 31, 2014, on other Starz series titles.

Dissatisfied in the low reception, the BBC and Starz have shelved plans to continue the series, saying now it was only intended as a miniseries anyway. (Humbug!) That is one crying shame, because this epic has it all: Drama, romance, betrayal, sword and ax-play, assassination, beauty and horror without launching into overwhelming gross-out. I hope BBC/Starz reconsiders. In the meantime, treat yourself to an epic series that can honestly claim the name.

 Kay Reynolds

Choosing the cast for this series was very carefully done and gives this series an emotional tone that feels authentic. Excellent acting and costumes. In this series the physical violence of war takes a backseat to the love affairs, which I think is a good choice. Bedroom scenes are very well done and remind you that history was created by men and women who would barely qualify for a driver's license in our century.  This is a critically important time in our shared history and I am glad that it is presented in a format that is more widely available. It is a coming of age tale for the protagonists and for the English world. Highly recommended.

Great Sex scenes (well for british) and decent acting cant change how this is more 'fantasy' than 'history'.  If this is fantasy, then where are my dragons?  Not even as accurate as 'The Tudors' from showtime (an obvious show to compare it to).  It does simplify a very confusing time of history (the cousins war) but its a show you watch with Google in one hand to check : "is that right?".  I really wanted to like the white queen, but it just doesnt have the direction and focus of its contemporaries.  Great when there are no other choices for "History with Boobs" and thats what you wanted to watch.

Mostly accurate historically. One of those rare focuses that Elizabeth Woodville wasn't super evil compared to all the other intriguers. The bedroom scenes and overall nakedness make it (dare I say it?) medieval. Goes slow once in a while as they information dump here and there or deal with subplots but worth it for Medieval enthusiasts. I'm going to give this a solid B grade.

I did not expect historical accuracy or archaic dialogue.  I  did expect great scenery, great costumes and a fun story line.  The White Queen delivers on that.  I loved the casting, the acting, the dialogue, the costumes, the story. . .

 I was sad to the see the series end.

If you are looking for a documentary or biography look elsewhere.  If you are just looking for a good story, don't miss this one.

In the spirit of full disclosure I do want to say that I wish they had done the love scenes more tastefully.  I do not like naked added to a move just because it can be.  There is no need.
Had so much suspense! Drama, and action. I love these kind of shows and the costume set was out of this world. Loved it!
There is so much history and intrigue!  The customs and the time were more savage then not.  Entertaining.  I have recommended this to friends.

It is beautifully done; costumes, interiors, presentation. History very well told. Very well directed, never boring one second.
Excellent actors. Wonderful History interpretation by  the author Phillippa Gregory.
I wish it is going to have a second season, I cannot wait to see the following.

I am not a fan of Philippa Gregory; however, I've long been interested in the Wars of the Roses and Richard III.  For example, I've read Paul Murray Kendall's and David Baldwin's biographies of Richard and Amy License's biography of his queen, Anne Neville, and I followed with great curiosity the discovery and verification of Richard's remains under a parking lot in Leicester.  Before purchasing the DVDs, I'd read a lot of negative comments about The White Queen miniseries but I'd also read positive comments about some of the performances.  I was particularly interested in Aneurin Barnard's performance as Richard, Duke of Gloucester, later Richard III.  The miniseries had already started filming when Richard's skeleton was discovered showing that he'd had scoliosis, which would have made one shoulder higher than the other as contemporary accounts described Richard.  The skeleton also showed that Richard was not as deformed as Shakespeare described so even though Barnard plays him without any deformity, his performance still seems closer to the historical Richard than Shakespeare's psychopathic crippled hunchback with a withered arm.

Other reviewers have discussed the historical errors so I won't go over them again except to say I found them very annoying and they did interfere with my enjoyment of the miniseries and are the reason I rated it three stars.  I was disappointed by the Special Features since many of them seemed to be rehashes of the same interviews.  However, since I primarily bought the miniseries for the performances, I'm satisfied.  In addition to Aneurin Barnard, I must especially mention how much I enjoyed Rupert Graves as the slimy, self-serving Lord Stanley and Amanda Hale as Lady Margaret Beaufort.

I love the Yorks and the War of the Roses and have read dozens of books (both fiction and non fiction) about this period in English History. I really looked forward to seeing it come to life, Instead of a mature and historically accurate portrayal of this group of complex and interesting characters, we were given a mess of inaccuracies, flat, boring personalities who (to quote the Bard) strut and fret their hour(s) upon the stage.......) If there had been fewer gratuitous bedroom scenes, less attention to graphic and badly done birth scenes, and death scenes perhaps more care could have been taken to assure historical accuracy.
This is a somewhat slow-moving show but I loved it. Elizabeth is a compelling character and the supporting cast is very good as well.

I truly enjoyed this mini-series, it was very intense and well done. I could tell it was filmed on location, the costumes were fantastic and every episode showed a slice of history that was well written and well acted. FANTASTIC!
Wounderful and very close to History. These people really did exist and this is a wonderful story. I highly recommend it.
Amazing mini series! Riveting! Keeps you on the edge of your seat! Hoping for a continuation of The White Princess!

I liked this show a lot.  Not quite as much fun as The Tudors, but the acting is great.  The show is pretty historically accurate in regards to the time frame in which certain things happened and takes a lot of liberty in certain other areas.  A fun watch for sure.

I don't think Ive mentioned this much, but I LOVE historical shows that are set in medieval times.  That particular period of time in history has always drawn me for some reasonIm not sure why.  Thankfully, there are plenty of titles available to keep my interest sharp:  PILLARS OF THE EARTH, THE TUDORS, just to mention a couple, and now THE WHITE QUEEN.  I have to admit, though:  of all the titles Ive watched, THE WHITE QUEEN is now one of my favorites!

I honestly wasn't expecting to like this series as much as I do.  It is gripping and raw, just like the subject matter of which it is about.  And the production value appears very high, which in turn makes for a more believable, and therefore enjoyable, series.

THE WHITE QUEEN is shot well and looks great onscreen.  Theres no doubt Starz spares no expense when it comes to this show, and the result is a realistic depiction of a dark time in Europes history.  Theres more throne-hopping and power-grab attempts in this show than a soap opera.  And, whats even better:  this show is based on fact.

I cannot say just how much of the show is based on true events, but I have done enough research to know the primary basis itself is sound.  These events did happen and involved the characters that we get to see onscreen.  But as for the particularsthe writers might have taken a few liberties here and thereIm just not sure.  Regardless, this show is full of drama, backstabbing, power clashes, battles, and romance.  You just cant ask for much more!

The acting in THE WHITE QUEEN is superb, with Rebecca Ferguson portraying the titular character.  Ferguson does an amazing job with her role, giving a fully convincing version of Queen Elizabeth.  The rest of the cast is stellar as well, with particularly memorable performances by James Frain as Lord Warwick The Kingmaker, Max Irons as King Edward, and Janet McTeer as Elizabeths mother, Jacquetta Woodville.

My sole complaint about the show is that it starts off pretty fast-paced before it finally slows down around the third episode or so.  This is a minor complaint, and I understand why it is done:  the events that lead up to the turmoil are only secondary in the show, and the production team has to quickly set the tone and basis for the show itself.  Still, I do feel it worth mentioning, just so you're not caught off guard should you give the show a look.

And I highly recommend that you do.  THE WHITE QUEEN is one of my favorite shows out right now, and I am looking forward to season two.  This season hits store shelves tomorrow, so make a note.
Well written and acted with plenty of suspenseful drama, as well as historical accuracy. Kudos to the writers and producers of this historical show.

I just purchased all 10 episodes of this series on iTunes for $16.99 in standard definition. I saw on Facebook yesterday evening that it was available for early digital download, and was so happy to hear of this! I have only seen the first episode, so I'm really looking forward to seeing how the story of the White Queen is depicted by the Starz network.

iTunes also offers this series in high definition (HD) for something like around $25.99. So if you don't mind owning the show digitally, I would very much recommend buying it from iTunes. It's much cheaper than buying it online (no S&H fees) and if you have your accounts synced through Apple's iCloud, you can watch the show on any of your Apple devices. :-)
could not view this DVD on our player, it was not compatible. would like to send it back but cannot!

I could not even play it on my blue ray.  The discs which were sent to me were made for blue ray players in other countries.  I need a new set of the White Queen Series which works for Blue Ray players in the US.
SOM

I am a big fan of Tudor history, and as this leads up to the Ascension of Henry Tudor to Henry VII, I enjoyed this quite a bit.
It is of course historical fiction, so everything it portrays isn't true. I was not surprised to see that they chose to portray Elizabeth Woodville trading a lookalike to take her son Richard's place; it fits in with so many novels I've read of the time period, and people want to believe that something like that happened. It didn't, though, so it irked me that it was included.
Also, the idea that it was Margaret Beaufort or her son, Henry Tudor that killed the princes in the tower. Puh-leeze. While Richard was still king, the whole country was talking about how the princes had disappeared and all he would have had to do is show the country they were, in fact, still alive. The only reason he would not do that is because, well, he couldn't. They were dead. I can come up with no other logical reason that he would not just put the rumors to rest once and for all. People love a conspiracy theory, the idea that history got it wrong and it was the more unconventional view that is more correct. It's the reason so many people are fascinated by the Kennedy assassination and the idea that it was a conspiracy and there was more than one shooter.
Although sometimes history gets it wrong, this time, history got it right. Richard III murdered the princes in the tower. Just once I'd like to see a fiction that portrayed what really happened and not this fantasy that Richard was this great guy who was framed.

Forget historical accuracy. Done that? Good, because "The White Queen" has very little, even less so than the books by Philippa Gregory upon which they are based. The sooner you accept that, the more you can enjoy a mini-series that doesn't claim to be anything but a loose dramatization of the War of the Roses, starting from 1464 with the meeting of King Edward IV and Elizabeth Woodville, and ending with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485. The time was ripe for a dramatization of the War of the Roses given the immense popularity of George R. R. Martin's A Game of Thrones and the subsequent HBO television adaptation, for the author has made no secret of how much this period of English history inspired his own work of fiction. In fact, for fans of the books, it's hard not to watch "The White Queen" without drawing correlations between the two: Henry Tudor's situation is very much like that of Daenerys Targaryen, whilst Robert Baratheon seems to owe his existence to King Edward IV. Cersei Lannister might well be a less-than-kind depiction of the titular White Queen, and even the emblem of the famous rose sigils of Lancaster and York can be found in the fictional Tyrells' standard. It stands to reason that if you enjoy one, you'll enjoy the other. But what "The White Queen" brings to the table is an emphasis on the women that were involved in the period, namely Elizabeth Woodville (wife of King Edward), Anne Neville (daughter of the man known as "the kingmaker") and Margaret Beauford (mother of Henry Tudor). Far from being passive observers to the drama, the mini-series makes good on its promise to depict the events from their eyes, and has them right in the midst of the intrigue and violence that characterizes this tumultuous period. Worth noting however is that this is not so much a miniseries about the War of the Roses, but an adaptation of author/historian Philippa Gregory's take on the events in question. Based on three of her books: The White Queen,The Red Queen and The Kingmaker's Daughter, various plot-points and characters are based on *her* specific understanding of what really happened, a relatively important distinction to keep in mind when you watch. Some historical figures are cast in an unsympathetic light (poor Duchess Cecily gets the worst of it, portrayed here as an embittered old harridan), whilst others can come across as noble heroes or helpless victims. Gregory's rather notorious reputation for distorting the facts to suit her favourites or to increase the levels of drama (seriously, don't believe *anything* you see in this show regarding Richard III's relationship with Elizabeth of York) means that everything seen here should be taken with a pinch of salt. But you could have probably assumed some degree of historical inaccuracy simply by watching. From the perfect skin and whitened teeth of the actors, to the visible drainpipes on the buildings and rubber-soled boots worn by the men, to the inexplicable decision to film the Battle of Bosworth FIELD in what is clearly a FOREST, there's not a huge amount of effort in keeping it realistic. But the main points of what became known as the War of the Roses are all touched upon: the controversial marriage of King Edward to Elizabeth Woodville, the Mad King and the Bad Queen, the on-going warfare between York and Lancastrian households, George of Clarence's execution, the mystery of the Princes in the Tower, Richard's stressful reign as king, and finally the invasion of Henry Tudor's forces. Emerging from the ensemble cast are several stand-outs: James Frain as a scheming Lord Warwick, Rupert Graves (best known as Lestrade from Sherlock) as the opportunistic Lord Stanley, and Rebecca Ferguson as the titular White Queen, who combines beauty and charisma with steel and fire. Veerle Baetens also has a small but unforgettable role as Margaret of Anjou. For me however, it's Aneurin Barnard as King Richard III and Amanda Hale as Margaret Beauford who really steal the show. Barnard's portrayal of Richard throws him into a far more sympathetic light than what we are used to, freeing the man from the most famous depiction of him as the black-hearted villain in Shakespeare's play. Here Richard is an honourable but conflicted man, grappling with a fraught political situation and driven to the edge by circumstances: the product of bad luck, wrong-headed decisions, treacherous counsel, and enduring rumours surrounding the disappearance of his nephews that he cannot be rid of. Hale depicts Margaret Beaufort as a terrifyingly fanatical woman, engrained with the belief that her son Henry Tudor is destined to be king and not afraid to stamp out anyone who might get in the way of that. Combining hypocrisy with sincere piety, ruthlessness with moments of regret, and godliness in the struggle against her own vanity, she ends up dominating every scene she's in. If there is one weak note it's that Henry Tudor is not given particularly strong characterization, and for such a pivotal figure in the drama he ends up too bland to garner much of an opinion of him one way or the other. Because of the format of the miniseries, several established characters drop from the action without warning once their roles are complete: Duchess Cecily, Margaret of Anjou and the Countess of Warwick are such narrative casualities, and you'll have to turn to Wikipedia to get an idea of their eventual fates. Likewise, the ending itself is quite abrupt, and it'll be interesting to see if Starz will follow through on its promise to adapt Philippa Gregory's The White Princess in order to continue the story of the surviving characters. Speaking of which, it's worth pointing out that the Starz and BBC versions of "The White Queen" differ in a number of ways. The Americans were treated to more racy sex scenes, but there were also a few other bits and pieces that were either deleted or added, including a scene that puts an entirely new spin on what was really going on between Richard III and Elizabeth of York. There's no doubt that even though the men are the movers and shakers, the women are the protagonists, with a particular emphasis on how they try to negotiate the pathways of influence and power. Whatever else you may think of the miniseries as quality television or as an accurate depiction of the period, I can appreciate that the women remain the focus throughout, something that's still rare enough in historical dramas to warrant praise.

What a grand and fabulous "escape"! Each episode was historically interesting and the romance between Edward and Elizabeth was very powerful. The chemistry with Max Irons and Rebecca was very enjoyable. Elizabeth's mother was one of the best parts of the series. She was strong and confident and she passed that onto Elizabeth. All of the actors were very good.

I give this first season 5 stars because it was well written the costumes were great
for this era the  Acting out standing. this series should win a award in all catagories
I am hooked on films from the 14th , 15th and 16th century. I watched the entire series on Stars, I have my pre-Order in and would like to know when it will be released
I hope I do not have to wait until Sept. or Oct. 2014 before it is released. For every one who likes this time in History you cannot go wrong with the White Queen.
Such an AMAZING show. I can't get enough of it. All the characters are beautifully played and its amazing how human nature is portrayed. Highly recommend!

I really, really enjoyed The White Queen.  And what impressed me the most is how historically accurate this production was in the most part, save some minor things.  Sure, people who are anal about historical detail may complain that there were no zippers and drain pipes in 15th century England, as apparently UK viewers did.  But I tend to be more forgiving as long as they get the history right.  The story of these three women (Elizabeth Woodville, Anne Neville and Margaret Beaufort)and their schemes is so compelling that it makes for great TeeVee drama.  I also enjoyed some of the subplots,  including that Elizabeth's mother, Jacquetta of Luxembourg, believed herself to be descended from the water goddess Melusina. I enjoyed the witchcraft subplot and if you read some of the historical accounts, witchcraft is a constant theme.  I assure you that after you are done watching this, you will want to research more on your own about the period known as The War of the Roses.

Most amazing mini-series I have ever had the pleasure to see. I am ordering this and re watching! I am also pre-ordering the next book in the series. This author is amazing and the movie was breathtaking. I am now in love with this era and all those who belong to it. Thank you BBC and thank you Starz.

Love this, It's roughly based on historical facts, We all know there are many versions of history, the witchcraft in the series is "television". They take some true facts, some speculations, whatever and make a very interesting and fun series to watch. People need to lighten up, for television......I loved it! Great acting too!

Once you start watching THE WHITE QUEEN you may get hooked. I am not current on my historical knowledge of this period. None the less, I will just say that there is a certain voyeuristic appeal to this series. There is a lot of underhanded plotting and conspiracy and sexual promiscuity to keep you watching and making sure you come back for more. You may need a score card of the characters and the events as you get deeper into the series. Your sympathies with certain characters and their circumstances may change as you get into the thick of it. It is captivating. That is for certain.

There has been a huge amount of laughably pompous grouching about the supposed inaccurate historicity of this series. Yes, the 'facts' have been altered or ignored in some cases. But who knows the 'facts'? Anyone who claims to know is simply a fraud. The only real facts to consider are that the series has some excellent acting and provides an interesting, informative and engaging starting point for anyone who wants to do their own research on this lesser known period of English history. Does anyone really believe Shakespeare's history plays are historically accurate? If not how dare they adapt them and make them into films! Next thing you know people will be saying that the bible is a historically accurate account of human history. Dear me!

I was home sick with a horrible cough and happened upon The White Queen mini series On Demand.  I was captivated within the first 10 minutes.  The story drew me in like no other.  This time period is intriguing and disturbing at both the same time.  I loved the costumes, hair design and interior decorating and the accents of the actors was so pleasant.  I may just go ahead and read the books now.  I would definitely recommend this mini-series. Yes there is hope in TV after all!

This miniseries is that adaptation of the three historical FICTION books, The White Queen, The Red Queen, + The Kingmaker's Daughter.  Be aware, it is FICTION and there are a lot of inaccuracies against historical fact.  It's based on the War of the Roses.

If you can suspend belief, and just watch it as a beautiful medieval mini-series (facts be damned!) it's very, very good. Lies, betrayal, death, sex, glorious costumes, good actors & actresses and more.  If you loved Camelot, you'll love this!

However, if you're a stickler for historical accuracy, then pass on this. Since I'm not a stickler for accuracy, I enjoyed it immensely.

Breathtaking costuming & sets. I just loved it, and plan on buying the miniseries.

I watched some of the episodes on cable and also read the book. The author did a fair job of making an unlikeable character sympathetic, although she had to do it by making Margaret (Henry VII's mother) into an unsympathetic person. I found that the movie concentrated far too much on the sex scenes and not enough on the actual plot also. But then, this is a fault of most made for cable channel movies. Witness "Game of Thrones!"

For starters, I could never get past the first episode because of how dull and disgusted I was with one scene in particular. The acting is good, but there were other things severely lacking in the series which also turned me off of it rather quickly.

For starters, I was able to pick out zippers on several of the costumes. You don't like these sorts of things for immersion purposes - it takes you out of the story and you have a hard time believing what is going on is actually set back in time.

I found the style of filming perhaps a bit odd. The picture wasn't as crisp as I would have liked it to be. The style reminded me of the series Rome, however Rome pulled it off a lot better in every way imaginable.

Secondly one thing that really bothered me was when the main character, and her main love interest - the future king, at the time were first starting to get together.

[spoilers for episode 1]
The scene bothered me because he was basically going to rape her, and the only reason he didn't was because she pulled a knife on him, and threatened to kill herself. Personally I hate when things like sexual assault are used as romance devices. Yes, this was something that frequently happened in the past. HOWEVER, how is something like this supposed to convince me that she is so in love with him, and he with her? (Yes, I am aware she actually did want to sleep with him but wasn't going to because of the fact she knew she would be easily tossed aside if she slept with him right away and because of the shame in doing so - but no means no, regardless of the character/person's reasonings for refusal and the male character should have respected that. Which would be historically inaccurate but at least it would give me a reason to actually believe in some sort of...relationship between them.) I seriously doubt a woman would fall head over heels for a man like that.

It just totally broke immersion and offended me for personal reasons.

Now, while I have not read the White Queen, or the series of books off of that one, I have read Phillipa Gregory's books before. So those who are saying she is historically accurate either have no idea what they're talking about or are just going off what other people are telling them. In several of her books most of the major plot points are factual but a lot of things she inputs are pure fiction. While they are historical fiction books, I'm just pointing out that this is likely the same way. It really doesn't hinder from the story for those who aren't really into the time period, but for those who are it's something that breaks the immersion.
Bought as a gift because it looked like a good series.

Loved this story.  Fictional history, but very captivating.  If you don't mind a little visual love-making and nudity, it is great entertainment.  The story line was so good I actually purchased the White Princess - the story of the daughter of the White Queen.
I will watch this many times.

This grabbed us from the first episode. So sad to know there is only one season.

Tightly written, edited abd superb acting. Its a delicious alternative to dessert

I normally do not like shows such as this one, but I wanted to watch something different. After the first episode I was hooked. I watched the whole season in 2 days! It really has got me interested in the history of these families! It was very entertaining!

Too bad that few seems to make a show without gratuitous nudity. I'm not prude but frankly I can't care less to watch women breasts and people "doing it".
Aside that the all show is a fantasy made up of wild speculations,writers don't seems to have bother to check much of the historical accounts, from ladies with unbounded hairs and no hairdresses; to the accounts of the real characters of the war of the roses.
And what is with Lady Margaret Beaufort ? Why in the show a staunch Lancastrian will tell her son that he is to be King with Henry Vi still alive with a live healthy male heir? Wouldn't that be treason(to the Lancasters ) ? And why is she portrayed as a nut job?

A lot of good actors,I didn't like the performance of Rebecca Ferguson ( Elizabeth Woodville ) or Faye Marsay ( Anne Neville) , I did like the cast of Max Irons ( Edward IV) , Aneurin Barnard ( Richard III ) , David Oakes ( George, Duke of Clarence) and James Frain ( Richard Neville  Earl of Warwick).
Janet McTeer (Elizabeth Woodville's mother) stole the show.

All said if I have to watch  historically implausible shows I prefer to stick withThe Game of Thrones.
really enjoyed watching this series...well done.
FANTASTIC SEASON!!!!
YESSSS!
Did not want it to end!
